course_title: Schenk-, erf-, overdrachtsbelasting en Estate Planning
lecturers: ['AHE Bruin, LL.M', 'JE Kreukniet, LLM', 'JHP Anastacio Teixeira - Stigter', 'mr.dr. E Boomsluiter', 'W Verstijnen']
text:
Inhoud Het erfrecht en het huwelijksvermogensrecht worden op hoofdlijnen behandeld. De student maakt voorts kennis met de Wet op belastingen van rechtsverkeer 1970 en de Successiewet 1956. Van de Wet op belastingen van rechtsverkeer 1970 wordt alleen de overdrachtsbelasting behandeld. Bij bespreking van de overdrachtsbelasting wordt ook ingegaan op de samenloopproblematiek met de omzetbelasting en wordt tevens stil gestaan bij de cumulatie met de schenkbelasting. Bij de behandeling van de Successiewet 1956  wordt vooral ingegaan op de begrippen: 'al wat krachtens erfrecht of schenking wordt verkregen' en 'fictieve verkrijging’. Er wordt uitgebreid aandacht besteed aan de bedrijfsopvolgingsfaciliteiten. Estate Planning wordt vanuit diverse invalshoeken bezien, zowel nationaal als internationaal. Leerdoelen Na dit blok bent u in staat om:
  • de hoofdlijnen van het Nederlandse erfrecht en het huwelijksvermogensrecht weer te geven en uit te leggen;
  • in een casus de familierechtelijke elementen te identificeren en daarvan de gevolgen voor het Nederlandse erf- en huwelijksvermogensrecht te beoordelen;
  • de hoofdlijnen van de schenk-, erf- en overdrachtsbelasting weer te geven en uit te leggen;
  • in een casus de elementen van schenk-, erf- en/of overdrachtsbelasting te identificeren en daarvan de gevolgen voor de heffing van genoemde belastingen te beoordelen;
  • in een casus de samenloop tussen overdrachtsbelasting en schenk-, erf- of omzetbelasting te identificeren en een conclusie te geven over de gevolgen van deze samenloop;
  • in een casus te identificeren of sprake is van een fictieve verkrijging als bedoeld in de Successiewet 1956 en daarvan de gevolgen voor de heffing van schenk-, of erfbelasting te beoordelen; en
  • in een casus te analyseren wat de schenk-, erf-, overdrachtsbelasting en familierechtelijke gevolgen zijn en daarover een gemotiveerd advies aan een belastingplichtige te geven.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud In this course, students will be introduced to science fiction as a major genre in cinema and  literature, but also in video games, music and other media. Science fiction has the ability to invent and prevent the future, but also to provide extremely precise analyses of societies. By studying its different past representations, we will try study how science fiction contributes to the understanding of our present, but also the shaping of our future.
 
Science fiction and media (A History of the Future) is the first course organized by CHIFT (Community for histories of the future), the platform based at Erasmus University aiming at studying and stimulating the production of science fiction in the Netherlands.
 
Note: This course has mandatory lectures. Leerdoelen
  • Introduction to film studies
  • Introduction to science fiction as a media genre
  • Use of science fiction to develop academic skills
  • Use of science fiction to broaden media studies

course_title: Science-based practice in the field of Child and Adolescent Psychopathology
college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud
De kinder- en jeugd GGZ maar ook het werkveld van de schoolpsycholoog heeft grote behoefte aan goed gekwalificeerde ‘scientist practioners’, dat wil zeggen psychologen die in hun dagelijks klinisch handelen oog hebben (en houden) voor recente wetenschappelijke inzichten en ontwikkelingen en van daaruit gebruik maken van ‘evidence-based’ diagnostiek en behandeling.
 
In dit derde blok in de Master Kinder- en Jeugdpsychologie zullen de studenten leren zich op te stellen als echte scientist practitioners. Ze zullen geconfronteerd worden met klinische en leerproblemen, waarvoor ze een wetenschappelijk gefundeerde oplossing moeten bedenken. Voorbeelden zijn: het selecteren van goed gevalideerde diagnostische instrumenten voor specifieke problematiek, het zoeken van de optimale (evidence-based) behandeling voor een kind met een bepaalde stoornis, het bekijken van evidence-based preventieprogramma’s, het onderbouwd kunnen adviseren van collega-psychologen. Tevens wordt er aandacht besteed aan de professionele attitude.
Leerdoelen Een belangrijke doelstelling van dit blok is studenten te leren een brug te slaan tussen het wetenschappelijk onderzoek en de academische vaardigheden enerzijds en de dagelijkse praktijk van de kinder- en jeugdzorg in de GGZ en het onderwijs anderzijds. Inhoudelijk zullen problemen behandeld worden uit verschillende relevante K&J-psychopathologiedomeinen die in eerdere blokken nog niet echt aan bod gekomen zijn. Hierdoor heeft de student aan het eind van de Klinische Kinder- en Jeugdmaster kennis gemaakt met alle belangrijke stoornissen uit de kinder- en jeugdpsychopathologie.

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
lecturers: ['E. Buitenhuis - Linssen', 'L.M.R. Nijs - de Langen', 'prof. dr. J.G.G. Borst']
['dr. AA Strelkov', 'dr. CDC van der Veeke', 'LIS Giel, MSc', 'VM Butot, MSc']
text:
Inhoud What is this strange thing called ‘modern science’? Where does it come from? And why do we need it? This course, the first of the academic skills curriculum, is the students’ introduction to scientific practices. It is concentrated on acquainting students with the historical and philosophical conditions in which modern science arose; the specific character of scientific statements vis-à-vis rivalling forms of knowledge; different approaches to objectivity; the crucial role accorded to (various) scientific methods of inquiry; and the position and functioning of modern science in society. Drawing on science and technology studies, this course emphasizes the practical and concrete character of scientific practice, engaging students through a series of examples with the above set of concerns. These examples will be designed to closely map onto a set of pressing and troubling societal matters of concern, e.g. the climate crisis. In so doing, this course prompts students to critically reflect on the contested and contestable character of scientific knowledges, equipping them with the capacity to understand and critically reflect on the distinction between science and non-science, as well as engage in debates about the role of scientific knowledges in society more broadly.

Leerdoelen

J van Poppel', 'mr. K Schriek', 'mr. NP Arzini, LLM', 'mr.dr. E Boomsluiter', 'mr.dr. EW Ros', 'N Cohen', 'prof.mr.dr. AW Schep', 'prof.mr.dr. MMWD Merkx', 'prof.mr.dr. W de Wit', 'S van Kreijl']
text:
Inhoud Het schrijven van een scriptie van 12 000-16 000 woorden (10 ects) is een verplicht onderdeel van de masteropleiding Fiscaal recht. Voor de studenten van de variant Directe belastingen geldt dat het onderwerp van hun scriptie betrekking moet hebben op directe belastingen; voor de studenten van de variant Indirecte belastingen zijn dat de Indirecte belastingen.
Het schrijven van de masterscriptie Fiscaal recht is alleen mogelijk met deelname aan het door ons aangeboden scriptietraject. Indien u de wens heeft om in het collegejaar 2018 – 2019 af te studeren, dan dient in ieder geval uw scriptie vóór 26 juni 2018 goedgekeurd te zijn door uw scriptiebegeleider. Indien de scriptie vervolgens wordt goedgekeurd door de tweede lezer, kan de scriptie worden verdedigd tijdens de afstudeerbijeenkomst van eind augustus 2019. 
 
Het scriptietraject bestaat uit de volgende verplichte onderdelen:  
  • Aanwezigheid tijdens de scriptievoorlichtingsbijeenkomst inweek 38;
  • Themaregistratie in week 40;
  • Goedkeuring scriptieonderwerp en aanmelding in het scriptievolgsysteem vóór 25 januari 2019;
  • a. Studenten variant Directe belastingen: eerste afspraak met scriptiebegeleider vóór 8 maart 2019.
b. Studenten variant Indirecte belastingen: deelname inleidende discussiebijeenkomst 6/7 februari 2019.
  • Deelname aan Fiscaal Confrontatievak (Start in week 12)

Let op: U kunt alleen aan het Fiscaal Confrontatievak deelnemen als u aan de verplichte onderdelen 1 t/m 4 hebt voldaan. Dit zal voorafgaande aan het Fiscaal Confrontatievak actief worden gecontroleerd.

Het is aan te raden op tijd met de scriptie te beginnen. Uit ervaring is bekend dat vooral de eerste fase van de ontwikkeling van een scriptie (bestaande uit de keuze van het onderwerp, de literatuurverzameling en het inlezen) veel tijd kost. Met nadruk zij hier vermeld dat een eventueel in het bachelorwerkstuk behandeld onderwerp niet mag worden 'uitgewerkt' tot een masterscriptie. Het onderwerp van de scriptie dient tijdig aangemeld te worden door middel van het invullen van het 'Aanmeldingsformulier scriptie (Master) Fiscaal Recht'. Na goedkeuring van het onderwerp door de sectie Fiscaal Recht ontvangt u bericht met daarin de naam van de toegewezen scriptiebegeleider. Na goedkeuring ligt het onderwerp vast. 
Met nadruk zij hier vermeld dat niet eerder aan een scriptie kan worden begonnen dan nadat het aanmeldingsformulier is ingeleverd en u bericht heeft ontvangen over het toewijzen van een scriptiebegeleider. 
 
Uw scriptie moet binnen twee collegejaren na aanvang van het masterscriptietraject door uw scriptiebegeleider zijn goedgekeurd. Daarna vervalt uw scriptieonderwerp. U dient dan opnieuw het gehele scriptietraject te doorlopen. Dat geldt niet voor het Fiscaal confrontatievak, indien u dat vak al met een voldoende heeft afgesloten. Indien u in het collegejaar 2018/2019 start met uw scriptie dient uw scriptie dus uiterlijk aan het eind van collegejaar 2019/2020 goedgekeurd te zijn door uw scriptiebegeleider.
  Leerdoelen 1.         De student kan zelfstandig een fiscaal juridische probleemstelling formuleren;
2.         De student kan zelfstandig een onderwerp op het gebied van het belastingrecht, de systematiek en de methodologische aspecten ervan, beschrijven, analyseren en beoordelen;
3.         De student kan de voor het onderzoek relevante bronnen verzamelen, ordenen, analyseren, beschrijven en verantwoorden;
4.         De student kan een fiscaal juridisch vraagstuk plaatsen in een bredere context, waarbij in elk geval een van de volgende aspecten wordt betrokken:
  • Een (een multi- of interdisciplinair) vraagstuk of case uit de beroepspraktijk
  • Een of meerdere juridische deeldisciplines
  • Europees en/of internationaal recht
  • De maatschappelijke rol van het recht
  • Andere wetenschappelijke disciplines
  • Ethische perspectieven
5.         De student kan op basis van aantoonbare kennis van en inzicht in de wetenschappelijke discipline op een gevorderd niveau een originele bijdrage leveren aan de wetenschappelijke kennis;
6.         De student kan zelfstandig op zijn leerproces reflecteren, nieuwe nationale en internationale ontwikkelingen in het fiscale recht signaleren en zich eigen maken; en
7.         De student kan zelfstandig zijn wetenschappelijk fiscaal juridisch onderzoek, onderzoeksuitkomsten en –voorstellen, zowel schriftelijk als mondeling, presenteren aan een juridische en aan een niet-juridisch onderlegd publiek, en deze bovendien ook beargumenteerd verdedigen.

Inhoud

text:
Inhoud

The course starts by introducing the Semantic Web, and ontologies as the cornerstone of the next generation Web. After that, the most relevant Semantic Web data representation languages (XML, RDF, and OWL) and data query/transformation languages (XPath, XQuery, and XSLT) are presented. Some applications of the Semantic Web for building Web Information Systems for finance, marketing, logistics, or information retrieval are also given.

The students will work in teams on several assignments related to the application of the Semantic Web for developing Web Information Systems. The students will write a report describing the proposed solutions.

Leerdoelen
  • Know what the Semantic Web technologies are.
  • Understand what a Semantic Web ontology is.
  • Be aware of the usefulness of Semantic Web technologies for developing Web Information Systems.
  • Be able to develop a Semantic Web ontology.
  • Be able to query a Semantic Web ontology.
  • Propose Semantic Web solutions for current problems that Web Information Systems face in finance, marketing, logistics, or information retrieval.

course_title: Seminar Advanced Corporate Finance: Corporate Governance
lecturers: ['dr. CS Pfeil', 'dr. DL Urban', 'prof.dr. I Dittmann']
text:
Inhoud

Corporate governance analyzes two conflicts of interest that arise in the financing of the firm.
The first is the conflict between shareholders and the firm's management. While shareholders usually want to see a high return on their investment, managers might have a different agenda. They could try to use the firm's funds for their own interests, or to build an empire that is big but unprofitable. We will discuss this problem and its two main solutions: monitoring by a big shareholder and incentive contracts that give the managers a share in the value they created for the firm.
The second conflict of interest emerges between controlling shareholder and minority shareholders. The controlling shareholder might try to "tunnel" money from the firm into her own pocket and thereby to expropriate minority shareholders. Depending on the legal environment, there might be many ways to do this. We will discuss the relevance of this problem and its implications for the ownership structure of the firm and for a firm's ability to obtain outside financing.
Against this background, we will discuss corporate governance laws and codes, the role and composition of the board of directors, executive compensation, the design of financial securities, mergers and acquisitions, and shareholder activism.
This seminar provides you with an opportunity to gain a deeper understanding about what good corporate governance is and why it matters. The course covers some theoretical and legal issues, but its main focus is on empirical research and insights. Therefore, we will analyze, discuss and criticize the methodology used in the empirical research. Hence, this course also aims at building a critical view on any empirical results presented to the student. In two group assignments, you will apply your knowledge and your skills to two different types of tasks.
Active participation in and a strong commitment to this course are a prerequisite. You are expected to present pieces of the literature and to prepare for in-class discussions. You will also present your own results, ask questions, mention doubts and express your ideas in the class discussion. Hence, learning group dynamics is a positive (and important) side effect of this course.

Leerdoelen

Students have knowledge of and insight into the theory of conflicts of interest within a firm.
Students have knowledge of different corporate governance standards currently in use and why they matter.
Students have knowledge of state-of-the-art techniques to resolve problems of endogeneity in empirical settings of corporate governance.
Students are able to critically discuss in class other authors’ empirical results.
Students are able to confront alternative empirical findings and evaluate their respective strengths and weaknesses.
Students are able to design and execute in groups a small scale empirical study.

Extra Oral participation during seminars counts 50% towards the final grade.

course_title: Seminar Advanced Corporate Finance: Empirical Corporate Finance
text:
Inhoud

The seminar is intended for students in their final master's year who want to obtain a thorough understanding of corporate finance, which examines the financial decisions of firms. Topics include capital raising, mergers and acquisitions, and payout policy. The lecturer will present recent empirical insights and techniques. During the course, students engage in presentations, discussions, and conduct research. More specifically, students are asked to work on weekly readings, present pieces of the literature, bring up subjects of discussion as preparation for the sessions, participate in group discussions, and perform empirical research in a group.

Leerdoelen

In this course, students will:

  • get acquainted with state-of-the art research in empirical corporate finance
  • learn techniques and methods used in empirical research
  • learn the tools necessary to work independently on a master thesis in empirical corporate finance
  • learn to master a challenging topic and perform research in a group
  • improve verbal and written communication and presentation skills
  • learn to critically analyze results and reflect on conclusions drawn from these results

course_title: Seminar Advanced Corporate Finance: Private Equity
lecturers: ['dr. CS Pfeil', 'dr. JCM Kil', 'prof.dr. JTJ Smit']
text:
Inhoud

This course follows a problem-solving approach that synthesizes ideas from game theory, real options, and strategy for corporate decision-making. Corporate finance and corporate strategy have long been seen as different sides of the same coin. Though both focus on the same broad problem, investment decision-making, the gap between the two sides -- and between theory and practice -- remains large. This course synthesizes cutting-edge developments in corporate finance and related fields -- in particular, real options and game theory -- to help bridge this gap. The course covers a wide range of valuation examples, such as firm valuation, private equity acquisition strategies, R&D investment in high-tech sectors, joint research ventures, product introductions, investments in infrastructure, and oil exploration investment. The course will be given in close cooperation with people and organizations that are active in corporate finance, such as private equity investors, investment banks, and consultants. The course Corporate Finance and Strategy is structured in two modules. The first module introduces you to both traditional and new valuation principles for strategic investment. We review the basic concepts and foundations of the building blocks:

  • Traditional DCF-valuation (WACC- and APV-method)
  • Strategic management
  • The valuation of real options
  • Games and bidding strategy

This part provides an overview and develops step-by-step the various principles useful for valuation and analysis. Questions addressed include amongst others:

  • How can one determine the value of a project or a firm?
  • What is the value of a license that gives the firm an option to invest in commercial production of a new product?
  • How is the optimal investment policy influenced by competition? How does competition affect the premium being paid in M&A?

In the second module we discuss various applications and examples of private equity investment, acquisitions, and initial public offerings. Lectures by guest speakers will be an integral part of the course and provide an opportunity to become better acquainted with corporate finance in practice. This course provides the fundamentals for the seminar Advanced Corporate Finance and Private Equity.

Leerdoelen
  • Students have knowledge of and insight into fundamental economic theories in corporate finance (real options, game theory and behavioral theory).
  • Students have knowledge of different types of acquisitions and how they are structured and financed.
  • Students have knowledge of and insight into strengths and weaknesses of using different types of valuation models, in the context where they can be applied.
  • Students are able to apply valuation models in a variety of contexts, such as firm valuation, private equity acquisition strategies, R&D investment in high-tech sectors, investments in infrastructure, and oil exploration investment.
  • Students are able to form an opinion based on different perspectives acquisitions and private equity investment.

Inhoud

Students will improve their understanding of the key concepts of investments and asset pricing, such as:

Multifactor models
Cross-sectional anomalies
Quantitative investment strategies
Performance evaluation of professional asset managers

and be able to implement and empirically test these concepts using rich data sets and programming skills.

This seminar is complementary to the course FEM11074 - Advanced Investments; Its successful completion is highly recommended. NB: The seminar is much more empirical, 'hands-on' than the FEM11074 course. Knowledge and skills acquired will be beneficial for both professional investors as for academic research (theses).

Leerdoelen

Students gain knowledge of and insight on asset allocation.
Students gain knowledge of asset pricing models.
Students are able to construct and apply optimal portfolios.
Students are able to test asset pricing models and anomalies.
Students are able to construct and evaluate investment strategies.

Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Decrease of ECTS and workload from 12 ECTS to 10 ECTS. Extra Grading is based on research papers, asset management game competition, a presentation and participation in, and quality of, the discussion.

course_title: Seminar Advanced Money, Credit and Banking
text:
Inhoud

Money, credit, and banking (MCB) are the tools at our disposal to bring our dreams of the future immediately to the present. This is true for country politicians dreaming of full employment, corporate managers dreaming of innovative growth, and individuals dreaming of a home for their family.

This course discusses the role and impact of MCB by bridging the link between academia and practice. Well-known theories and frameworks on public money and credit (e.g., inflation, monetary policy and central banking,), private money and credit(e.g., financial markets, and the financing of firms) and banking (financial institutions) are presented and evaluated.

How does a modern financial institution or publicly held firm operate and how is it financed? What is the role of central banks, both in the past as well as today, and how does this relate to their mandate? How has financial intermediation changed with technology? And what impact does the role of regulation play in financial markets? All these developments are creating various opportunities -and risks- as we speak, and not understanding this properly can seriously damage your wealth.

Leerdoelen

At the country level, you will understand the role of MCB in the most important financial crises (the US mortgage crises from 2008, the Euro crisis from 2011, and the current COVID-19 situation that is still evolving), and in the policy responses to these crisis. You will also learn how countries have coped with these crises through unprecedented monetary innovations, and what consequences this has had on the real and financial economy.

At the firm level, you will learn about the role of MCB in the financing of corporations. You will understand the promise and pitfalls of financial market innovations, and bust the myth of the widely held public firm. This will allow you to better understand existing and future financial products and foresee vulnerabilities in financial markets.

Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Different reading list compared to last year.

lecturers: ['dr. JE Rose', 'dr. MFM Hainguerlot', 'dr. SC van der Zee', 'mr. AC Peker, MSc']
text:
Inhoud

Behavioural economics models systematic deviations from the standard economic model. This seminar will show how to take into account these deviations to improve the design and implementation of business strategies and public policies.
The course will consist of guest lectures and case studies in partnership with companies and public organization.

Leerdoelen

Learn how to apply behavioral theories.
Identify a problem and analyze its economic and behavioral aspects.
Develop a solution and give practical recommendations.

Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Students will work on two instead of three tasks. This allows students to spend 3.5 weeks on 1 research projects, allowing them to spend more time on the literature review, data collection and analysis, and report. A second change is that students now also get a grade for their research proposal (10% for each research proposal). Extra Assessment:
Essays
Reports
Oral presentation.

lecturers: ['dr. J Yu', 'drs. KD Miljoen, RA', 'drs. NA de Vos, RA']
text:
Inhoud
  • Introduction to Auditing.
  • Audit Research.
Leerdoelen

To gain insights into auditing practice and research.

Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar We will be teaching on campus if the rules permit this. Belangrijk om te weten

lecturers: ['dr. M Hendriks', 'DT O Ceallaigh', 'prof.dr. C Li']
text:
Inhoud

In the seminar Behaviour, Health and Wellbeing students will learn to combine the knowledge and skills obtained in the major courses to analyse and possibly influence behaviour related to health and wellbeing. In particular they will work on two themes: (i) healthy behaviour, (ii) wellbeing; with four possible angles
(a) Measuring and analysing behaviour and well-being (e.g., Why do people procrastinate going to the gym?)
(b) Understanding the role of people’s own responsibility (e.g., Should overweight people pay more health insurance premiums?)
(c) Making policy recommendations (e.g., How can we incentivize or nudge healthier behaviour?)
(d) Evaluate the impact of policies (e.g., Can we test whether the incentives work using a field experiment?)

Leerdoelen
  • The students learn to apply data analysis skills to analyzing real dataset;
  • The students apply behavioral and health economic theories to solve real-life problems;
  • The students learn to conduct a well-designed online survey;
  • The students learn to write scientific reports;
  • The students learn to present scientific research;
  • The students learn to work in teams.

Inhoud
  • Evolution from efficient market to behavioural finance
  • Biased investors
  • Biased managers
  • Interaction between rational managers and behavioural investors
  • Biased third party (central bankers, analysts, policy makers, governments, etc.)
  • Behavioural finance in the digital economy
Leerdoelen

After completing this seminar, students can

  • understand the fundamental difference between the efficient market view and the behavioural view of the financial market
  • learn about specific behavioural distortion in major economic agents
  • quantify the impact of behavioural bias in individual investment and corporate decisions
  • obtain basic skills in thesis writing and data analysis
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar The working load is going to be adjusted according to the reduction of course credit.
Course literature can be updated to maintain the content relevance. Extra The grade is based on group case work, discussion participation, and individual presentations.

Inhoud

This course aims at improving our understanding of financial markets and asset returns, by applying insights from psychology and other behavioural sciences. Traditionally, the finance paradigm seeks to understand financial decisions by building on optimal acting investors and market forces that correct mispricing; that is, it assumes people behave rational. However, abundant evidence, reveals that this paradigm is too restrictive and in many circumstances gives a poor description of people's behaviour. We (being people) do not always act in the best way possible. In fact, in many decision situations we make mistakes that result in non-optimal behaviour.
Using interactive sessions, the first part of this course will examine various influential behavioural biases and their implications for financial markets and decisions. The second part of the course will consider how behavioural principles can turn into a profit by studying how behavioural biases affect the behaviour of market participants and prices. Finally, the course will learn you how trading strategies can be developed based upon various behavioural pitfalls.

Leerdoelen

See: https://osc.few.eur.nl/cgi-bin2/authen/edu/eindterm/leerdoel_toon.pl?vaku=4680

Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Every year the course is updated with the latest financial and market insights. This could be for example sustainable investing, covid developments and cryptocurrencies. Extra Grades are based on presentations, preparation of and active participation in classroom sessions, individual assignments, and/or a group research assignment in which you will apply behavioural principles in investing.

course_title: Seminar Case Studies in Applied Econometrics
text:
Inhoud

Students work in small groups on a specific theoretical or empirical econometric problem. Topics stem from international macro-, financial, and micro-econometrics, and may be provided by institutions, policy-makers and/or firms. Each group has its own supervisor(s). Groups meet with their supervisor(s) on a weekly basis, to discuss the progress of the research and relevant issues and questions. During the end of the term, each group writes a report about its research. A plenary session is scheduled at the end of the term, in which the research project is presented by members of the group and discussed by members of another group, followed by a plenary discussion.

Leerdoelen
  • The student learns how to formulate a proper research question with testable hypotheses.
  • The student learns to decide upon the correct data and appropriate econometric model to answer the research question.
  • The student learns how to do a research project in a team of 4 students.
  • The student learns to apply his econometric knowledge to do proper econometric inference.
  • The student learns to use estimation output resulting from an econometric analysis to answer the research question and to report his research in a scienfic report and a presentation.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar The only change in the set-up of the course is the introduction of peer review: at two moments during the seminar, each team will provide detailed and constructive feedback on the research project conducted by another team. Belangrijk om te weten Travel costs for three meetings at the firm / institution that provided the research project.

course_title: Seminar Case Studies in Business Analytics and Quantitative Marketing
lecturers: ['dr. A Archimbaud', 'dr. C Cavicchia', 'dr. K Gruber', 'dr. M Khismatullina', 'prof.dr. D Fok']
text:
Inhoud

The students are divided in small groups. Each group works on a research question. Usually this research question is put forward by a company. First, the relevant literature is studied. Next, the research question is translated in one or more models. To estimate the parameters of the models, (company) data is used. Much attention will be paid to the selection of the best possible model, given the research question. This model can be any model dealt with in the various courses, but it can also be a model that needs to be developed by the students themselves. The model parameters are estimated, and the model results are interpreted within the light of the research question. The final results will be presented in a scientific report and a presentation.

Leerdoelen
  • Learn how to formulate a research question and how to translate it in an econometric/statistical model.
  • Learn how to obtain a well-specified model using techniques from econometrics/statistics/machine learning.
  • Learn how to use the outcomes of an analysis to answer the research questions.
  • Reporting of academic research in the form of an article.
  • Reporting of academic research in the form of a presentation.
  • Work in a team.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Each year new cases are studied and the set of cooperating companies changes. Belangrijk om te weten A few visits to the cooperating companies may be required, this may come with travel costs.

course_title: Seminar Case Studies in Data Science and Marketing Analytics
lecturers: ['dr. CS Bellet', 'dr. R Karpienko', 'dr. V Avagyan', 'FJL van Maasakkers', 'prof.dr. ACD Donkers']
text:
Inhoud

In the seminar Case Studies in Data Science and Marketing Analytics, students get the unique opportunity to solve real-world management problems working on real data and collaborating closely with real companies. Solving the business case hinges upon six data-science talents that determine the success of a data science project. These talents are the foundational pillars of the course structure: subject expertise, data wrangling, data analysis, storytelling, design, and project management (Berinato 2019, Harvard Business Review).

The case starts with formulation and conceptualization of the research question and immersion into the relevant literature to gain subject expertise. Next, students wrangle the data acquired from the company behind the case. Then, students first conduct relatively simple data analysis and obtain preliminary insights. Afterwards, they use more advanced data-science methods to validate these preliminary insights and enrich them. Based on these insights, students develop their stories to engage the company to take action. Finally, students design effective visual communication and present it to company management. Throughout this period, students apply project management to organize effectively various activities and teamwork.

What students say about this course:

  • Challenge ourselves with a real-life case from a well-known company under demanding conditions.
  • The seminar was for us the ultimate test of applying those methods we learned during the previous courses using a real-life dataset.
  • The course showed that real life business problems are much more challenging than many of the toy examples we learn in other courses.
Leerdoelen

Students will learn and sharpen the following skills
a) precisely formulate a general management question as a specific research question
b) review the literature in terms of theory and methods related to the research question
c) determine the data requirements for answering the research question
d) find and implement a suitable analysis technique to answer the research question, given available data
e) answer the research question based on the outcomes of the selected technique
f) provide recommendations for management based on the results
g) communicate effectively within the team and with external relations
h) reflect on the provided solution.

Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar We further finetuned and clarified the tasks and timelines involved in solving the case. Extra There is no resit possible.

lecturers: ['dr. G Moroni', 'dr. IV Ossokina', 'M Bastiaans', 'prof.dr. HD Webbink']
text:
Inhoud

During the seminar you learn about different ways to conduct policy research, using recent cases in policy evaluation.
Examples are:

  • What can we learn about the impact of unemployment policies using quasi-experimental research designs?
  • Can we measure the effect of additional funding for schools with a regression discontinuity design?
  • How to set up a fiel experiment to analyze the effects of teacher performance pay?
  • What does social-cost benefit analysis tell us about the costs and benefits of the Olympic Games?

Students are expected tot discuss and present policy research during the seminar.
Finally, students are expected to do an empirical case study, do research assignments, and write a policy research paper.

Leerdoelen
  • To learn the main techniques in the field of treatment/ policy evaluation: randomized controlled trials, instrumental variables models, regression discontinuity models, difference-in-differences models.
  • To understand the underlying assumptions of the main models and the differences with the standard approaches as linear regression and matching models.
  • To understand the main techniques of social cost benefit analysis.
  • To be able to assess the credibility of policy evaluation by applying the knowledge of the main models and their assumptions.
  • To be able to assess the quality of a social cost benefit analysis.
  • To be able to present the scientific evidence for a specific policy cases and assess the credility of this evidence.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Several papers for the assignments have changed, in addition we continue with the presentation of the empirical case studies. Extra
  • Feedback notes on selected papers
  • Presentations about selected papers
  • Assignments for data analysis
  • Empirical case study 
  • Within two weeks after a possible failure, a rewritten policy paper needs to be handed in.

Inhoud

The goal of the seminar is to increase your knowledge and understanding of the relevant issues in commodity trading from a Finance perspective. This means that we’ll investigate how commodities can be traded and which factors influences prices of the physical product and derivatives, and how the above relates to investments in assets connected to the commodity trade.
The seminar will benefit from a strong cooperation with Viterra BV , and will therefore focus on agricultural commodities in particular.
Commodities will be studied from 2 directions: the ‘trade-perspective’ who has to find a way to formulate a view on the market, and act accordingly; and the ‘risk manager's perspective’ where one has to judge if the trades do not combine to excessive risk for the company. As always, these topics will be tackled both through the analysis of empirical data and cases, as well as literature study.

Leerdoelen

Understanding how the risk-return relationship works in commodity trading, including aspects related to supply and demand, competitive pressures, logistics and risks associated with physical delivery.
Being able to identify empirical data that can be used to predict commodity prices, and argue those choices.
Being able to estimate econometric models that allow for price predictions
Being able to manage risks related to commodity trading, both quantitatively and qualitatively.

Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Some streamlining in order to fit the seminar in a 10 EC set-up, update of the instructions for the assignments. Extra
  • The final grade is determined based on individual work including discussion contributions (oral and written), presentations, a discussion leadership, and the group assignments with a common grade.
NB: the full 8 weeks will be used, with evaluations after that. Do not plan to be outside the country before the last working of the block, even if the last session has already taken place.

Inhoud

The seminar 'Competition Policy' mainly deals with theories of competition and public competition policy. Few people would dispute the importance of markets for our (material) welfare. But if these markets are important, then it also matters whether they function well. This is why we study competition theory and policy.
We will consider the nature of market power by firms and the strategic interaction (competition) between them. We will look at which strategies firms may use to be better off themselves and what consequences those have for consumers. And even when such practices would be harmful per se, it remains the question whether it can and should be forbidden. During this course we will gain insight into the factors that the answers to these questions depend on and why that is the case.
In this course we will discuss the four main topics of Competition policy. These are:

  • Market power, and the measurement thereof;
  • Collusion between firms;
  • Mergers between firms;
  • Predation, Entry deterrence and other abusive behavior by firms.

We will analyse these topics using game theoretic tools. Moreover, we will relate our insights to the actual competition laws and policy.

Leerdoelen
  • Reproduce and interpret concepts in Competition Policy.
  • Discuss the relation and frictions between (1) EC competition law and economic theory; as well as between (2) economic theory and its practical application.
  • Apply economic theories regarding competition policy (collusion, predatory behavior, mergers) to analyse, explain and evaluate and advise about the economic policies pursued by companies, governments and institutions.
  • Present scientific papers on Industrial Organization(explain model, results and why those results follow from the model), and use such papers when evaluating competition cases.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar This year I will ask students whether they prefer to have a quickened schedule of lectures and seminars, so that all topics are covered sooner (which is preferable w.r.t. papers).
Also students will present a draft of their paper in class.
  Extra The retake will replace the examination only. In order to receive a sufficient grade a minimum grade of a 5,0 on the examination is required.
Grades for paper and other assignments remain valid until the end of the academic year.
NB: Application to this seminar implies obligatory attendance in case of admission!

lecturers: ['dr. I Honarvar Gheysary', 'dr. MG Gabarro Bonet', 'dr. NRD Dwarkasing', 'dr. VV Volosovych']
text:
Inhoud

In this seminar we discuss the key topics in corporate finance, with particular attention to practical applications. The subjects include investment and capital structure decisions by businesses. During the seminar, students will present and discuss academic papers and case studies, including a company valuation where we try to arrange a guest lecture of a valuation expert or company CEO/CFO. The literature mainly consists of articles from the reputable academic journals, as well as chapters from the leading practitioners books and internationally acclaimed finance textbooks. Students are expected to solve the cases and actively study the assigned literature, that is, read and present the articles/chapters, write discussion points related to the readings, and actively participate in group discussions.

Leerdoelen
  • Learning more advanced techniques and theories regarding the valuation of companies.
  • Having first-hand practical experience with valuing a company and/or a investment project.
  • Learning of how the investment and capital structure decisions are made by corporations.
  • Understanding the difference between price and the fundamental value.
  • Learning to work individually on mastering the class material and in group on a valuation case.
Extra The final grade is determined based on discussion contributions (oral and written), a presentation, discussion leadership. and the group work on a case.
Attendance of all sessions is required.

Inhoud

Corporate governance analyzes two conflicts of interest that arise in the financing of the firm.
The first is the conflict between shareholders and the firm's management. While shareholders usually want to see a high return on their investment, managers might have a different agenda. They could try to use the firm's funds for their own interests, or to build an empire that is big but unprofitable. We will discuss this problem and its two main solutions: monitoring by a big shareholder and incentive contracts that give the managers a share in the value they created for the firm.
The second conflict of interest emerges between controlling shareholder and minority shareholders. The controlling shareholder might try to tunnel money from the firm into her own pocket and thereby to expropriate minority shareholders. Depending on the legal environment, there might be many ways to do this. We will discuss the relevance of this problem and its implications for the ownership structure of the firm and for a firm's ability to obtain outside financing.
Against this background, we will discuss corporate governance laws and codes, the role and composition of the board of directors, executive compensation, the design of financial securities, mergers and acquisitions, and shareholder activism.
This seminar provides you with an opportunity to gain a deeper understanding about what good corporate governance is and why it matters. The course covers some theoretical and legal issues, but its main focus is on empirical research and insights. Therefore, we will analyze, discuss and criticize the methodology used in the empirical research. Hence, this course also aims at building a critical view on any empirical results presented to the student.
Active participation in and a strong commitment to this course are a prerequisite. You are expected to present pieces of the literature and to prepare for in-class discussions. You will also present your own results, ask questions, mention doubts and express your ideas in the class discussion. Hence, learning group dynamics is a positive (and important) side effect of this course.

Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Research papers updated; fewer plenary sessions.

Inhoud

Marketing focus has been shifting from the product to the individual customer as the unit level of analysis. Managers are increasingly concerned with the long term profitability of customers; and with their ability to collect (and analyze) consumer data and manage both the value consumers provide to the firm and the value a firm can provide to the consumers. That is why Customer Intelligence and Customer Relationship Management (CRM) have become essential parts of the decision making process for successful firms.
This course will teach students how to gather data about consumers, and how to make sense of it in order to make decisions within the organization. The course will show students the benefits of using a systematic and analytical approach to marketing decision making, and will allow them to build their skills and confidence in undertaking such analyses and decision making in the context of CRM. A "consumer-focused" approach will enable students to acquire research techniques that provide more detailed insights into the behavior of customers.
The course is designed for students who have extensive background in or understanding of marketing research and marketing principles.

Leerdoelen

The course objectives are to:
Teach students how to identify a marketing problem and obtain reliable information to better understand the customer.
Provide students with an understanding of the role that data collection and analytical techniques play in enhancing marketing decision making in modern enterprises.
Provide students with the software tools that will enable them to apply the methods taught in the course to real marketing problems.
Improve students' skills in viewing marketing processes and relationships systematically and analytically.

After this course the students should be able to:
Identify the right context of the real life marketing problem where the data collection methods and models discussed in class can be applied.
Create effective measurement instruments aimed at gathering data about their consumers.
Explain the construction of key statistical models used to describe consumer behavior.
Use statistical software to conduct the analyses discussed in class.
Communicate the results to the general audience in an intuitive and practically relevant way.

Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Minor changes in some assignments compared to the previous year. Extra A sufficient grade for the written exam and the assignments is required to pass the course.

lecturers: ['dr. FM Elfers', 'dr. J Bae', 'dr. J Pierk', 'dr. Y Gan']
text:
Inhoud

The general objective of this course is to acquire methodological and analytical skills to analyze large datasets. The analysis of big dataset produces information that can be effectively used to improve decision-making and business outcomes.

Leerdoelen

Students should be able to communicate with data specialists and understand the strength and limits of data analysis in the field of accounting, auditing and control.

Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Evaluation:

50% weekly assignments:
Weekly assignments are mandatory and must be completed with sufficient quality; they are graded, and students need to score at least 5.5 to earn a “pass”. Students need to pass at least 3 out of 4 assignments to be able to take part in the final exam. If a student fails an assignment, there won’t be a “make up” assignment to improve the grade.

50% final exam: The minimum grade for passing the final exam is 5.0.

To pass this seminar the total grade must be at least 5.5 [(average grade of all assignments + grade of the final exam)/ 2]. Extra Assessment:
Group assignments (50%)
Final exam (50%)

course_title: Seminar Data Science for Marketing Analytics
lecturers: ['dr. A Tetereva', 'dr. C Cavicchia', 'dr. M van de Velden']
text:
Inhoud

In this seminar several data science/machine learning methods are treated sequentially. First, students acquire the basics behind various machine learning techniques after which they deepen their knowledge and understanding of the methods by implementing and applying the methods to real data.
We discuss and apply several "state-of-the-art" machine learning methods. Students are asked to critically assess, present and discuss the material. Reviewing state-of-the art methods and their application in business settings will help students to assess whether (and how) data can be used to help answer real world business problems.
What students say about the course:
"Exhaustive coverage of the main state-of-the-art machine learning techniques, from students to students learning approach"
“The best way to learn something, is by trying to explain it to others. You are forced to know every part and detail of the subject.”

Leerdoelen

Understanding various state-of-the art machine learnig (ML) methods.
Being able to:
Explain several state-of-the art ML methods do to a general audience.
Critically assess academic and public sources in which the ML methods are introduced.
Apply the ML methods using R.
Interpret and explain results of such ML analyses through presentations and written reports.
Carry out and write a short report on independent research in which ML methods are applied to a real data set.

Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar The methods/topics covered during the seminar has been updated to match small content of the introduction to data science course and the teaching format of the seminar.

course_title: Seminar Developing and Marketing New Products
lecturers: ['prof.dr. S Stremersch', 'prof.dr. V Landsman Schwartz - Schwartz']
text:
Inhoud

Innovation is the engine for growth in most modern firms. However, many organizations fail when bringing innovations to the market. The development and marketing of new market offerings is therefore arguably one of the most critical and most difficult challenges faced by any organization.
This course is a must-take course for anyone with an interest in innovation, new markets and entrepreneurship. We will go through each stage of the new product development process, from opportunity identification until product launch. Throughout the lecture series, we will use business cases, simulation games, recent articles from the academic literature, and many practical examples to illustrate recent developments in innovation and marketing and the possibilities to involve consumers in the process.

Leerdoelen
  • Students will broaden their knowledge in marketing innovations.
  • Students will understand basic conceptual frameworks within the new product development process.
  • Students will have been introduced to possibilities to involve consumers in the innovation process.
  • Students will have been introduced to quantitative tools to study new markets and new products.
  • Students will be able to carry out basic analyses of innovative company cases which are geared towards illustrating basic marketing concepts.
  • Students will be equipped with conceptual frameworks to help them make better marketing decisions regarding the marketing of innovations.
Belangrijk om te weten Students are required to purchase the digital reader (course-pack) for this course. The course-pack contains access to cases that are analyzed in the course sessions.

Inhoud

The definitive decision on the main topic(s) will be made before the start of the course. During the course, students will get an in-depth theoretical and empirical background into the economics of main topics of the course.
Guest lecturers with strong expertise in the main topics and policy makers will be invited. Students are expected to prepare lectures well. During the lectures students will present articles from a list of required reading to the whole class. Active student participation in the course will be rewarded.
During this course, each student will be writing a policy paper on an important aspect of the main topic(s) of this course. Students will provide a theoretically sound and empirically founded policy advice to solve the policy problem under consideration. Since policy questions will generally be very broad, different students will analyze different sub-questions in their papers.
The lecturers provide assistance with writing the papers. Students need to defend their analysis in a class presentation.

Leerdoelen
  • To require in-depth knowledge about one of the most pressing policy issues of our time, such as the eurocrisis, global warming, inequality, taxation of multinationals or the corona-crisis.
  • To understand the economics of a policy question from theoretical literature.
  • To judge the relevance of theoretical arguments using empirical evidence.
  • To weigh different theoretical arguments based on their empirical validity.
  • To formulate a policy advice based on sound economic reasoning, backed up by solid empirical evidence.
  • To defend the analysis of a policy question in a presentation.
  • To write an economic policy advice that contains i) theoretical analysis, ii) empirical evidence of theoretical arguments iii) weighing various arguments iv) formulating a policy recommendation.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar By and large no changes to the set-up. We update the literature and need to exchange a few guest lecturers. We try to improve the timing within the discussion lectures to facilitate discussion in class. Extra The assessment of a student will be based on;
  • his/her presentation during the discussion classes (10%),
  • his/her participation in the discussion classes (10%),
  • the policy paper (groups of four students) and the presentation of it (60%),
  • and the oral examination on the literature discussed in the course (20%).

Inhoud

Information and decision rights are key elements in any decision-making process. This seminar looks at both elements in some depth.
We study theoretical contributions to the literature. Each session lasts three hours. The first session is a plenary lecture on cheap talk and doubles as a session to refresh your knowledge of dynamic games of incomplete information. During all other sessions pairs of students explain papers to other
pairs of students. Pairs are formed before or during the first session. Preparing a presentation in pairs and next explaining it to another pair of students is the best way to master the material.

Leerdoelen
  • Gain a better understanding of information and decision rights in decision-making processes.
  • Learn how to read academic papers.
  • Learn how to present and explain academic papers in a small group of students.
Extra
  • Depending on the number of students, the exam is either oral or written
  • Obligatory attendance at all sessions.
  • You have to earn a pass grade both for the exam and for the course as a whole.

course_title: Seminar Economics of the Public Sector
text:
Inhoud

This seminar aims at building up your knowledge of scholarly research in the area of public economics. Each session is devoted to a single academic paper on the economics of the public sector, where students will actively present and discuss the paper. Parallel they will be writing an own research paper.

Typical topics covered in the seminar include :

  • Minimum wage policy
  • Behavioral public finance
  • Education
  • Crime
  • Politics

The precise topics included and organisation of the seminar depends on the number of students who end up being assigned to the seminar. All the relevant information will be given before the seminar begins via Canvas and discussed during the first meeting of the seminar.

Leerdoelen

The main aims of this course are to:

  • familiarize students with scholarly research on the economics of the public sector;
  • enable students to explain and critically reflect on the methodology and findings of recently published academic research;
  • give them hands-on experience at doing research on policy economics and writing a research paper.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Some minor changes based on last year's evaluations:
- One additional plenary q&a session on the research paper
- Grades on discussion points & participation (25%) are now evenly split between discussion points (12.5%) and participation (12.5%)

course_title: Seminar Empirics of Trade and Development
text:
Inhoud

This course provides students with an overview of the latest empirical work in the fields of international trade, economic geography, and economic development.
Students will become acquainted with the most recent empirical methods used to uncover the determinants of economic development, with a focus on the role of trade and (economic) geography.
The aim is to give students the necessary tools to read and understand the latest empirical work that claims to uncover the role of international trade, (economic) geography in general on countries' or regions' overall level economic development, as well as their role in driving income inequality. Upon finishing this course students are able to critically evaluate these studies and judge their validity.
The seminar starts with a brief crash course on the most recent econometric methods used to identify the important factors determining trade and development patterns around the globe. Subsequently, we will critically discuss some of the most influential recent empirical contributions in the fields of international trade and economic development.

Leerdoelen
  • This course provides the students with the basic tools to read and understand the latest empirical work that claims to uncover one or more important factors determining their overall level of economic development - with a special focus on trade and (economic) geography.
  • Upon the completion of this course, students will be able to critically evaluate modern empirical studies in the fields of international trade and development economics and judge their validity.
  • This course provides students with a thorough understanding of the issues faced by any empirical researcher that aims to establish causal effects using non-experimental data.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Updated literature/papers, to include the most recent published papers on the topics discussed.

Inhoud

The first part of the seminar focuses on how energy markets can better accommodate renewable energy sources to reduce carbon emissions. You'll study energy and emissions market prices and the relation between carbon emissions and renewable energy supply. Your task is then to formulate a critical solution to the issues you have discovered. During the second you work in a group on a case about the impact of sustainability on company value, its stock price and borrowing potential.

Leerdoelen

1. To be structure abstract business like problems and to solve them.
2. To understand how financial economic thinking helps to provide solutions for renewable energy and other sustainability topics.
3. To be able to think more critically about solutions for sustainability issues.

Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar The cases that the students will work on are updated. Extra The grade for the course is the weighted average of an individual paper (50%), and a group paper (50%).

lecturers: ['dr. NL Lehmann', 'dr. PYE Leung', 'dr. Y Gan']
text:
Inhoud

In this course, we will focus on empirical financial accounting research topics, such as the capital market implications of accounting information, earnings properties and disclosures. The course is given in a seminar format: sessions take place in small groups of (up to) 24 students and will consist of active discussions about existing research Besides reading academic research, you will learn to apply the knowledge to solve or provide advice to issues in practice. This will be achieved through in-class discussions and assignments, as well as a separate group assignment in which you will write a policy advice on a current topic of debate, drawing from existing academic research.

Leerdoelen

At the end of this course, students should be able to:
1. Identify and discuss mainstream research topics in financial accounting research.
2. Describe and evaluate theoretical arguments in accounting research.
3. Evaluate whether the empirical research design of a paper can provide an answer to the posed research question.
4. Describe and draw their own conclusions from the empirical findings (tables/graphs) of a paper.
5. Summarize academic knowledge to advise on issues in society or practice.
6. Develop and present your own arguments founded in good reasoning.
7. Engage in discussion about financial accounting topics with peers.

Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar The format has changed slightly - the plenary session will now take place as a separate general plenary at the start of the week, in which the lecturer will lead the discussion of the week's topic first as a general introduction. The student presentations/discussions of relevant papers follow in the second half of the week in a separate two-hour session.

Inhoud

This seminar is one of the most important parts of the bachelor program; it will take a large part of your time: 12 ECTS in 8 weeks is 42 hours of work per week on average. During the seminar a broad array of subjects will be presented dealing with recognition, measurement, presentation and disclosure of financial information. Subjects that are discussed are among others:

  • General aspects of financial reporting, such as conceptual frameworks, information needs of users, international developments, accounting policies and earnings management;
  • Recognition and measurement of specific items in the balance sheet and profit and loss account, such as tangible, intangible and financial assets, equity, provisions, and liablities;
  • Special subjects, such as consolidation, mergers and acquisitions, foreign currency, accounting changes, financial instruments, leasing, segment reporting, environmental/sustainability reporting, cash flow statements, management discussion and analysis;
  • Analysis of the annual financial statements of a public company.
  • Students have to present papers, solve cases, prepare presentations and take part in the discussions.
Leerdoelen
  • Obtain knowledge about financial accounting and reporting.
  • Obtain insight in the recent law and standards concerning external financial.
  • Obtain the differences between Dutch GAAP and IFRS.
  • Understand the purposes of the annual financial statement.
  • Obtain knowledge in which way assets and liabilities and income and expenses in the annual financial statement need to be presented.
  • Be able to write papers of different subjects concerning the annual financial statement.
  • Based on recent literature students should be able to perform an presention during the course.
  • Be able to discuss within the group the relevance and interesting subject in a paper written by collegue students.
  • Be able to erform minutes of the college for the other student.
  • Be able to function as chairman, as discussiant and as secretary during the course.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Updated literature (academic papers). Extra There is no final (re)examination.

lecturers: ['B Van Os, MSc', 'dr. G Freire', 'dr. HJWG Kole', 'dr. JWN Reuvers', 'dr. M Grith', 'dr. O Kleen', 'dr. R Lange', 'dr. W Wang']
text:
Inhoud

Students work in teams of 4 on specific (theoretical or empirical) financial econometric research projects, which are supplied by firms in the financial industry (including asset managers, hedge funds, insurance companies, and pension funds). Examples include problems in asset pricing, portfolio management, risk management, and derivatives pricing.
Each group has its own supervisor(s). Groups meet with their supervisor(s) on a weekly basis, to discuss the progress of the research and relevant issues and questions. Each group writes a report about its research. A plenary session is scheduled at the end of the course term, in which the research project is presented by a member of the group and discussed by a member of another group, followed by a plenary discussion.

Leerdoelen
  • Learn how to formulate a proper research question with testable hypotheses.
  • Learn to decide upon the appropriate econometric techniques and necessary data to answer the research question.
  • Learn how to use the outcomes of an econometric analysis to answer the research questions.
  • Learn to report about the research project in the form of a (scientific) report and a presentation.
  • Learn to collaborate on a research project in a team with fellow students.
Extra This course is only accessible for students enrolled in the Master programme in Econometrics and Management Science.

Inhoud

The program starts with a general introduction to FinTech, followed by an in-depth treatment of major Fintech developments that offer promising business opportunities. This part forms the foundation of knowledge that students can apply in a comprehensive case study that will need to be solved. Students will get feedback on their assignments, so that they can improve over the weeks.

This course is not meant to be a technical course, but rather one training students to view specific use cases from a strategic perspective. We will, however, cover the technicalities behind FinTech developments to the extent that they contribute to your business acumen.

Leerdoelen

The purpose of this seminar is to equip student with the knowledge, skills and mindset to critically evaluate FinTech developments from a strategic perspective. Successfully completing this course will increase your academic understanding of financial innovations, but also enhance your skills when applying this understanding to practice by understanding the success of recently launched Fintech companies, map opportunities and threats from the perspective of traditional (financial) companies, and seeing opportunities to start your own business.

Professional skills include presentation skills, participating, organising, leading group discussions, and analysing case studies of varying complexity. Academic skills include understanding and evaluating academic studies and academic writing in English. Both sets of skills will be developed in both individual and group assignments.

Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar
  • Academic articles and online content are updated to reflect the latest developments in the field
  • New session on Tokens usage & market dynamics
  • Graded case studies are now preceded by "tentative" case studies that are peer-reviewed

Inhoud

Following the most recent trends in empirical research, this seminar will take a firm-level approach to the study of international trade. To have a firm grasp in understanding the empirics, we will start off with the “new” trade theory of international trade, its extension with heterogeneous firms, and the related gravity model of trade. We will then focus on the empirical research on heterogeneous firms and trade by studying and discussing frontier academic papers. The topics covered will include: self-selection into exporting, learning by exporting, multi-product firms, intermediaries in trade, and most importantly, the impact of trade policy shocks on different firms.

Leerdoelen

The purpose of this seminar is to provide students with an understanding of the role of firms in international trade. By completing this course, students will be able to answer questions such as: Why only a few firms export? How are they different than other firms? How do multi-product firms engage in international trade? What is the role of intermediaries in facilitating trade? What is the impact of trade policy shocks on different firms? Upon the completion of this course, the students will be able to critically evaluate empirical research, especially in identifying causal effects using micro-data to answer policy-relevant questions.

Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar The list of papers updated to reflect recent developments in research.

lecturers: ['dr. H Zhu', 'dr. NRD Dwarkasing', 'prof.dr. PAE Koudijs']
text:
Inhoud

In this seminar, we will explore Finance’s fascinating history to generate valuable insights for today’s world. The seminar is organized around four themes (1) securities markets, with special emphasis on how information is processed by financial markets, (2) limited liability, with special emphasis on entrepreneurship and banking, (3) banking and financial crises, with special emphasis on banking regulation and the real effects of crises, and (4) politics and finance, with special emphasis on the interaction between finance and people’s political attitudes. This seminar is relevant for all students who are interested in why today’s financial system looks the way it does, what lessons we can draw from past failures and successes, and the implications this has for how we should organize financial markets and institutions today. Tasks include the presentation and discussion of scientific papers. For the final (group) assignment, students will write a policy brief based on historical research. Alternatively, students will get the opportunity to develop a thesis proposal.

Leerdoelen

Students have knowledge of and insight into: the important role financial markets play in processing information, and how that information shapes real economic decisions.
Students have knowledge of and insight into: limited liability, and the role this plays in risk-taking decisions
Students have knowledge of and insight into: the central role of banks and other financial institutions, the way they operate, and the inherent risks they pose.
Students have knowledge of and insight into: how politics and finance can interact to have positive or negative impact on society
Students are able to: read, interpret and evaluate academic work.
Students are able to: translate academic findings into policy relevant insights
Students are able to: write a concise and effective policy brief
Students are able to: identify potential thesis topics from the topics discussed in class.

Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar This year, three lecturers co-instruct this seminar. They are Dr. Haikun Zhu and Dr. Narly Dwarkasing, as well as Prof. dr. Peter Koudijs as a guest lecturer. Each of the lecturers is responsible for two sessions on different topics. Extra Assessment:

Participation and discussion points               30%
Presentation / Chairing                                  30%
Group assignment                                         40%

Inhoud

Most traditional market boundaries have disappeared. Successful firms in sectors as diverse as consumer packaged goods, consumer durables, industrial goods, and services have discovered that traditional rules of competition – such as focusing only on the competitive interplay in each country separately – have changed dramatically in today’s globalized markets.
New strategies are determining who are the winners and the losers. Firms which respond proactively to the challenges of a globalized world outperform firms who are unable to adequately respond to a changed world. Firms cannot ignore this trend to globalization. Even if they decide not to be involved in the global or pan-regional (ASEAN, EU, Mercosur, NAFTA, etc.) marketplace, companies still face increased competition in their home markets because of nimble foreign competitors reaping the benefits of global strategies.

Leerdoelen

Knowledge of factors and criteria to determine foreign market attractiveness
Understanding the different ways in which brands can be rolled out globally
Understanding the impact of digitalization on global brands
Understanding the impact of sustainability on global brands
Implementing global marketing strategies that are a smart combination of global standardization, local adaptation, and worldwide learning

Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar This course has added a few more case studies. Belangrijk om te weten Students are required to purchase the digital reader (course-pack) and StratSim simulation for this course.

Inhoud

This seminar looks into the business of institutional asset managers. In particular, you will learn about pension funds that manage billions of dollars in assets and affect the lives of many millions of retirees, endowment funds that sustain major educational institutions, and sovereign wealth funds that benefit a whole nation. The goal of this course is to develop a broad perspective on the asset management business.

An array of different developments has been affecting the international asset management industry in recent years. In particular, the strong volatility in equity markets, interest rates falling to unprecedented low and even negative levels, extreme moves in oil prices and currencies, the availability of new asset classes and the ongoing aging of populations in many countries. Meanwhile, the amount of assets managed professionally has multiplied in the last decade and the institutions have become a major player in international capital flows.

The seminar is structured around three main topics. First, the course starts with analyzing the largest category of institutional investors based on assets under management, defined benefit and defined contribution pension funds. We will also study endowment funds and sovereign wealth funds, and compare the asset and liabilities of these institutional investors.

Second, the seminar will focus on the asset allocation policy implemented by institutional investors. We will answer two key questions. How do institutions decide on the level of capital to allocate to individual asset classes? How to implement the asset allocation? The seminar will discuss in detail the issues of diversification, portfolio optimization, trading costs, passive and active strategies. We will discuss not only traditional investments in equity and fixed income, but also investments in alternative assets, like private equity, hedge funds and real estate. The students will also work on a quantitative assignment that analyzes the added value of alternative assets for the current portfolio of a pension fund.

Third, the seminar will cover in-depth the governance and organizational complexities surrounding institutional investors. This part of the course will discuss the fiduciary responsibilities of institutional investors and study the role of socially responsible investing and institutional shareholder activism. An important question is whether investing in this type of funds has (positive or negative) consequences for institutional investors because of the inherent restriction of the universe of stocks.
We will also work on a case study of All Pensions Group (APG), the largest Dutch institutional asset manager. In this assignment, the students benefit from working under the supervision of Prof.dr. O.W. Steenbeek, who is Managing Director of Strategic Portfolio Advice APG, in addition to his affiliation with Erasmus University.

This seminar will be of great interest to students aiming for a career in the asset management business. A fundamental understanding of the issues in institutional portfolio management will also be beneficial for students focused on other areas of financial economics such as investment banking, corporate finance, governance, accounting, insurance and household finance. In addition, students will learn how to better manage their future personal wealth. To succeed in finance industry, you need to master the quantitative skills of a portfolio manager. To be a leader in this field, you also need a thorough knowledge of how markets and organizations function across countries.

Leerdoelen

The goal of this seminar is to get a better understanding of the way institutional asset managers invest large pools of financial assets.
Insights in the role of alternative asset classes in a portfolio, such as hedge funds, private equity and commodities.
Insights in the difference and between active and passive investment strategies and the implications for asset management organization.
Insights in the way a specific asset manager works by doing a case study and visiting the company.
Students will learn how to work in groups, participate in a discussion, critically read academic articles, present to an audience.

Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar No fundamental differences. One group assignment less than before. All classes in person on campus, apart from a few guest lectures. Belangrijk om te weten No additional costs. We are probably not going to visit a company this year. If we do, that would involve the cost of a train ticket to Amsterdam for those who don't have a public transport card. Extra The main elements for which you receive a grade are: group assignments (50%), presentation (15%), participation (15%), individual assignment (10%) and a small in-class exam (10%) at the end.
Obligatory attendance at all sessions.
Satisfactory result for assignments.
In-class presentations.
Active participation in class.

course_title: Seminar Interest Rates and Stock Markets
text:
Inhoud

This seminar covers several topics on interest rates and stock markets.
In particular, we discuss term structure of interest rates, interest rates modeling, cross-sectional stock returns, investor recognition hypothesis and financial crisis.
Students are expected to study and present the literature from renowned academic journals, lead and participate in group discussions. There are two assignments on empirical asset pricing.
In addition, you will present your own ideas and write a research proposal.

Leerdoelen
  • Understand empirical methods in asset price analysis.
  • Design interest rate modelling for security pricing.
  • Design portfolio selection methods and analyze their advantages and disadvantages.
  • Evaluate studies in the field of asset pricing and judge their contributions.
Extra Required attendance: all seminar meetings;
Active participation in seminar meetings;
Graded assignments include presentation, participation and assignments;
Satisfactory result for all assignments, presentation, and participation.

Inhoud

This course aims at providing exposure to relevant topics on international financial markets. Five main topics are covered: (1) sovereign default models, (2) international transmission of shocks, (4) the international transmission of monetary policy, (4) international risk sharing and the home bias puzzle, and (5) the effect of international capital flows on economic activity. We will cover both theories and empirical studies. This is a master course appropriate for students with previous knowledge on macroeconomic theory and/or econometrics and/or finance. The evaluation includes participation and presentations in class, homework and an essay.

Leerdoelen

De leerdoelen kunnen worden ingezien en veranderd worden via: https://osc.few.eur.nl/cgi-bin2/authen/edu/eindterm/index.pl .
The course objectives can be viewed and changed via this page: https://osc.few.eur.nl/cgi-bin2/authen/edu/eindterm/index.pl .

lecturers: ['dr. LE Westerink - Duijzer', 'dr. S Sharif Azadeh', 'prof.dr. D Huisman']
text:
Inhoud
