The seminar covers the application of different Operations Research techniques to a real-world application presented by a company. The particular cases vary from year to year and include public transport planning, vehicle routing, inventory control, etc.
The seminar builds forth on the theory given in all other masters courses. Moreover, good programming skills are required.

Leerdoelen
  • Students should be able to formulate a quantitative model for a specific logistic problem.
  • Students should be able to defend their model selection and be able to adapt standard operations research model to the sitation on hand.
  • They have to be able to formulate the necessary assumptions and evaluate their practical implication; Students have to be able to analyze data to come up with the parameter values needed for the model.
  • Students should be able to implement a method in a computer program and give advice for the problem on hand.
  • Students have to be able to interpret the results and write a management / scientific report as well a presentation on the results.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Students can choose between two new interesting and relevant cases. Extra Other obligations for the student:
  • Scientific report on their study:
  • Presentations on their study.

Inhoud

This seminar focuses on the design and use of accounting information for decision making and decision influencing. The emphasis will be on understanding how managers can design and use accounting information to help the organisation achieve its objectives. Some of the topics that will be discussed are Performance measurement, Incentives, Earning Management,Value-Based Management and Accoutning for non-profits. In this seminar learning will occur trough active participation, class discussion, and self-discipline. To enhance this, the professor will assign each student to a team consisting of 2-4 students. Each team has to write a paper on one of the topics of the seminar, assigned by the professor. Each team will present their paper in the session on that specific topic. One of the other teams  has to be the discussant team, and still another team is responsible for chairing the session and stimulate the discussion in class. Each team has to fulfill each of the different roles at least once. The professor will make a schedule at the beginning of the seminar that lists when each team has to perform a specific role. Please note that this seminar is one of the most important parts of the bachelor program. It will be very time-consuming: 12 ECTS  in 8 weeks is, on average, 42 hours of work per week.

Leerdoelen - Students have knowledge of and insights into the “state-of-the-art” in the academic management accounting and control literature on selected topics.
- Students are able to apply Management Accounting and Control concepts, theories, and research techniques.
- Students are able to conduct research in the field of Management Accounting and Control resulting in a seminar paper.
- Students are expected to actively participate in the class discussion, to present pieces of the empirical literature, to chair meetings, critically analyse research paper, and to write a paper based on corresponding group assignments. Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Last year, the seminar sessions were held online due to the Corona measures. As it appears, this year the sessions will be held on campus. Extra Obligatory attendance at all sessions.

Inhoud
  • Various management control systems are used by firms to assure the organizational goal can be achieved. This course discusses the commonly used control mechanisms such as performance measurement, pay-for-performance systems, target setting, promotion decisions and corporate governance. In particular, why are they used, what are the advantages and disadvantages, and how to apply.
  • This course also relies on cases from financial reports to help students build connections between theories and real-life problems.
Leerdoelen

This course aims at providing students with a thorough understanding of research topics of management control. Management control refers to management activities that can stimulate employees and managers to act in the way that organizational goals can be achieved in an effective and efficient manner. Management accounting research thus examines antecedents and consequences of different control methods and tools that rely on accounting information to motivate agents to behave in the desired manner. By learning these topics, students should be able to apply theoreis to practical control issues that commonly happen in firms.

Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar The set-up is similar to the previous year. This course uses different tasks to help students learn the theories and build the link between theories and practice. To help students better prepare for the master thesis, students this year will write a thesis proposal in this seminar.

Inhoud

Marketing strategy addresses firm opportunities to advance customer relations through research, analysis, and long-term planning. The fundamental goal is to gain a competitive advantage and maximize long-term profit. This seminar is designed to synthesize knowledge already acquired in core marketing and strategy courses, and then apply it to specific business cases. Therefore, the aim is not to gain new knowledge, rather to apply theoretical models and market research methods to real marketing problems. Students will work as individuals and in groups to learn about and analyze several interesting cases studies; then, develop actionable strategic marketing plans. Students will be expected to submit written plans and at times present orally.

Leerdoelen

This course attempts to help develop integrated marketing skills to succeed in business. It has a strong application orientation. Specifically, students will learn:

  • How theoretical models work in practice;
  • How to link different concepts and theories learned and apply them to real marketing cases;
  • How to successfully market products or services, as well as develop innovation strategies;
  • How to make optimal use of market research and analysis techniques in developing marketing strategies.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Updated textbook.

Inhoud

The seminar is organized around several key papers (and background reading) in the economics of organizations. Topics covered include the theory of contracts, theory of the firm, incentives and productivity, and vertical integration. Topics vary from year to year depending on the interests of the students.

Leerdoelen
  • Provide students with a toolkit for thinking about and dealing with problems inside organizations.
  • To learn about the state of the art in the economic theory of organizations.
  • To learn about the data and methods required to test the theory, and more specifically how field experiments can be used to glean insights about organizational theory.
  • To be able to assess inefficiencies relating to incentive problems and organizational design more generally and to evaluate alternative pay schemes and organizational structures that purport to alleviate such efficiencies.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Topics change from year to year depending on the research frontier. Structure is unchanged. Extra Grades are cumulative; a pass grade is required for the course as a whole.
Attendance is obligatory; class participation determines part of the final grade.

course_title: Seminar Ports and Global Logistics: Disruptive Scenarios
text:
Inhoud

Content
Scenario planning originates from the military. Scenarios allow military planners to augment enemy moves and get grip on the uncertainties of a dynamic battlefield in order to manage the deployment of troops and military assets effectively. Likewise, international businesses and multinational enterprises operate in various interconnected markets and are exposed to a great variety of risk, non-linearity and complexity. Think about the sudden but enormous impact of Covid-19 on the short term (quarantines, travel bans) and how it might impact on the long term (digital acceleration, deglobalizing supply chains). Scenario planning is used by international businesses as a strategic tool to cope with rapidly changing business environments that are often characterized by disruptions and uncertainty. Thinking in scenarios allow business leaders to augment possible futures on the fortunes of their company upon which they can define various options and strategic investment decisions. In this seminar students will learn how to apply scenario planning as a strategic management tool. Each group of students will write a scenario report for one real-world international company active in shipping, trade and logistics

Leerdoelen

Learning aim
The aim of this seminar is to apply scenario planning techniques and methodologies so that students can develop realistic future scenarios for the year 2040 on behalf of an international company in the shipping industry that operates in world full of disruptions and uncertainty.

Learning outcomes
After this seminar students are able to:
• Identify various trends and disruptions with an impact on ports, shipping and supply chains
• Generate large amounts of business intelligence from various sources and synthesize these into a coherent strategy
• Employ scenario planning methodologies
• Self-organize into groups and communicate results under time pressur

Inhoud The seminar has a theoretical and an empirical part, both of which try to confront insights from macro models with real-life problems faced by policy makers and central bankers. Ample attention is given to the challenges posed by the financial crisis to the macroeconomic profession. The theoretical part of the seminar takes stock of the current theory of macro and monetary economics and reviews a number of technical issues, such as solving a rational expectations model with forward looking agents. The analysis of DSGE (Dynamic Stochastic General Equilibrium) models and their linearization. We also study some of the recent developments. The empirical part of the seminar is devoted to estimating and experimenting with small scale macroeconomic models to be developed by the students in small groups.  Leerdoelen
  • Have up to date knowledge of current macro models.
  • Know how to estimate and simulate a small scale macro model.
  • Are able to analyze and manipulate modern macro models.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar New lecturer, content, structure and literature.

course_title: Seminar Recent Advances in Economics of Markets and Organisations
text:
Inhoud

During the seminar, academic research papers are presented and discussed by students. Moreover, each student works on a research project (which can, but need not be an extension of one of the papers) and writes a short note on this. Papers are chosen from a list of recent academic research papers on current topics in the economics of markets and organisation. These include both theoretical and empirical papers.

Leerdoelen
  • Learn about recent advances in both theoretical and empirical economics of markets and organisations.
  • Learn how to present an academic paper in the area of economics of markets and organisations.
  • Learn how to formally discuss an academic paper in the area of economics of markets and organisations
  • Learn how to perform a small-scale academic study, either theoretical or empirical, in the area of economics of markets and organisations.
  • Learn how to write a short essay reporting research findings.
Extra Obligatory attendance at all sessions.
Satisfactory results for essay, presentation, formal discussions in class (at least twice), discussion slides (twice a week), participation in general discussion.
As compared to last year, there will be a couple of sessions where students present their draft research proposal.

Inhoud

Cities and regions are going through a constant process of economic, social and spatial change. This applies to the most successful global cities but also to those cities that had to go through (or are still going through) a process of economic restructuring because their dominant industries collapsed. This continuous economic, social, and spatial development of cities can strengthen its competitive position but for cities struggling to reinvent their economies, it can be (and possibly still is) a painful process. Additionally, urban areas, companies and citizens increasingly face problems in terms of accessibility and mobility. Congestion, pollution and social exclusion are only some of the major challenges that decision makers have to address. And they have to do this in a fast-changing world; in recent years new forms of mobility (sharing-, electric-, micro-, floating-mobility) have developed at a fast pace. Finally, the recent COVID-19 crisis will most probably influence the way we travel for a while. Hence, the economic and transport development of cities and regions are topics that are high on the agenda of companies, policymakers, practitioners and academics.
In this seminar, the objective is to develop the ability to give strategic advice to stakeholders in order to increase their competitiveness. Students learn to use different research methods (i.e. data analysis, case study, surveys etc.) in order to come up with intelligent solutions to the most common urban and transport problems. These skills can be used by students when conducting research for their master thesis.
Some seminar sessions might include guest speakers’ presentations. In the last years this seminar has covered the following topics:
• Regional Economic Policies and Networks
• Travel Behaviour
• Smart Mobility and Transport Infrastructure
• Sharing mobility and mobility hubs
• Urban retail
These topics are discussed based on the latest scientific insights and real-life case study. Students are stimulated to use a variety of research tools to analyse actual challenges. This is an intensive course that combines interactive group discussions, the writing of weekly individual essays, (field) assignments as well as empirical group work and assignments.

Leerdoelen

The main aim of the course is to train students in the economic analysis of contemporary challenges in the fields of transport, and urban and regional development. More specifically the objectives are:
1. To deepen the knowledge on specific regional and transport problems by advanced scientific readings.
2. To develop the ability to apply research and methodological tools to analyse contemporary regional and transport challenges.
3. To develop accurate and sound economic strategic advice for stakeholders.
These aims will be achieved through interactive group discussions and the writing of individual essays and a group assignment.

Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Some of the seminar topics have been changed compared to last year based on students' suggestions and/or recent development in the fields or regional and transport economics. The set-up of the course remains mostly unchanged.

Inhoud

The financial sector constantly creates new products, services, and institutions. Some examples of paramount importance include financial The globalization of business paired with rapid technological changes, increased volatility in the financial markets, and extraordinary monetary policy measures has changed the risk profiles of many companies and banks dramatically. At the same time, derivative markets have grown accordingly and the routes to managing market and credit risks have expanded. As a result, many firms have embraced the concept of risk management. However, applying derivatives for risk management ('financial engineering') requires a deep understanding of their characteristics, their pricing and last but not least of the markets on which they are traded. This seminar is devoted to the analysis and management of risks and complements the course FEM11023 - Financial Risk Management. The seminar covers a wide range of derivative contracts, ranging from plain vanilla (forwards, futures, swaps and options) to more exotic (exotic options, weather and insurance derivatives) that will be applied in a trading game. Moreover, you will learn how changes in monetary policy and the macroeconomic environment affect the business models of financial institutions. We will also cover origins and consequences of recent crises, like the global financial crisis, or the COVID crisis. By means of group assignments, various practical and theoretical issues of derivatives, risk analysis, integrated risk management, and the changing role of banks for the real economy are explored in depth.

Leerdoelen

• Students have knowledge of and insight into the theory of financial risk management.
• Students have knowledge of and insight into recent developments in financial innovation.
• Students are able to apply standard measures to evaluate market and credit risks.
• Students are able to write a research assignment

Extra The final grade is determined based on individual work including discussion contributions (oral and written), presentations, a discussion leadership, and the group assignments with a common grade.

course_title: Seminar Stock Pricing and Investment Strategies
text:
Inhoud

Among the topics discussed are:

  • Seasonal anomalies, such as the weekend effect and the price momentum phenomenon
  • Cross-sectional anomalies such as the size effect and the value premium
  • Multifactor risk models for explaining differences in stock returns
  • Investor behavior, under- and overreaction
  • Mergers &: acquisitions from the perspective of shareholder value for both bidders and targets
  • Initial public offerings and underpricing from the perspective of the firm, underwriter, and institutional &: private investors
Leerdoelen
  • The goal of this seminar is to get a better understanding of the pricing process in stock markets, where an emphasis is put on empirical research in practice.
  • Insights in phenomena for which there is no empirically verified conclusive explanation such as mergers &: acquisitions and initial public offerings.
  • Insights in the measurement of (ab)normal returns and the risks, the interpretation of empirical results in relation to stock and firm features, and the construction of investment strategies.
  • Students are expected to actively participate in the class discussion, to present pieces of the empirical literature, to chair meetings, to do empirical research with stock and firm data, and to write short papers based on corresponding group assignments.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Only a few papers on the syllabus changed. Extra Grading is based on two papers, a presentation, discussion participation in class, discussion points and being a discussion leader.

Inhoud

To achieve its learning goals, this seminar combines a hands-on marketing strategy simulation (StratSim) with discussion-based sessions (lectures, coaching, and cases), which allows us to offer you important insights that can become the cornerstone of students' careers in marketing, consulting, corporate strategy, or entrepreneurship.
In particular, in many firms, there is a tension between tactical decisions aimed at improving financial returns in the short-term versus strategic decisions aimed at increasing the firm value in the long term. Thus, we will make strategic marketing decisions for simulated firms and for a total of 7-8 simulated years, which will allow us to feel the tension between short- and long-term strategies when devising strategies to gain market leadership in an industry.

Leerdoelen

Marketing is an integral part of today's business activities. However, it is not always clear how marketing leaders should make strategic marketing decisions. In this course, you will learn how to make strategic marketing decisions in a realistic environment.

A key concern of this course is to ensure a clear bridge between marketing strategy tools and concepts (what we could call the “theory” of strategic marketing) and how to apply such tools and concepts to make better evidence-based strategic marketing decisions (what we could call the “practice” of strategic marketing).

Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar We restructured the guest lecture sessions, especially the guest lecture and associated assignment on "resilient business models". We now focus more on rising trends in omnichannel marketing strategies.
  Belangrijk om te weten All students are required to purchase our digital reader (course pack) for this course ($49.95; approx. 42 EUR). The price of the course pack serves mainly to pay for the individual license of the StratSim simulation from Interpretive Simulations.
  Extra Assignments (100%):
Class participation (peer evaluation): 15%:
StratSim performance: 15%:
Stratsim reports (3): 45%:
Evidence-based strategic marketing report: 25%:

lecturers: ['AB Wismans, MSc', 'dr. G Antonecchia', 'dr. TLPR Peeters', 'S Ramezani', 'SDT Hoey']
text:
Inhoud

The content of the seminar is fourfold. Two group assignments:
1. Solving a business case on a strategy issue using relevant insights from the academic literature and available data to the best extent.
2. Collecting and summarizing research papers to give an overview of relevant research on a topic related to firm strategy Providing a critical assessment of the literature to identify a relevant research question for further research.
And two individual assignments:
3. Presenting a research paper in class to give an insight in relevant research on a topic related to firm strategy. Answering questions from fellow students and moderating a class discussion.
4. Writing a summary on each of the research questions discussed in class with critical assessment of the presented papers.
Example topics:
1. Can successful management practices be transferred across countries and firms?
2. What is the impact of top managers on the performance of firms?
3. Can firms acquire new technology by hiring workers?
4. What is the effect of entry regulation on economic performance?
5. Why are firms using other firms to produce their output?

Leerdoelen
  • Read and understand state-of-the-art economic literature on strategy, managerial economics and firm entry and exit.
  • Summarize and communicate insights from scientific papers on economics of strategy in a class presentation.
  • Search and analyse firm data in a group project to solve a business case related to entry strategy.
  • Write an informed opinion on current topics in strategy research based on relevant literature.
  • Conduct an in-depth literature review and define a relevant research question on a specialized topic in industrial dynamics and strategy.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Research themes change continuously in response to student interests and scientific developments. Extra N.B.: Application to this seminar implies obligatory attendance in case of admission!

course_title: Seminar Supply Chain Management and Optimisation
text:
Inhoud

This seminar gives a quantitative insight into the design of a supply chain. It provides a tool-box in terms of research skills (Excel skills and finding data) , theory and methods in order to be able to analyze and optimize supply chains, focusing on costs as well as CO2 emissions. We focus on a case for importing white goods from China to Europe. The case serves to get hands-on experience in the considerations for choosing between different transport modes (what to ship and what to fly), cost structures, selection of distribution network, port choices and locations of distribution centers. Finally we also evaluate environmental issues relating to supply chains. The required theory will be given in four courses at the start of the seminar.

Leerdoelen

To understand the effect of various supply chain drivers.
To be able to analyse a supply chain according to various characteristics.
To be able to apply supply chain design and transport chain models.
To develop the research skills and methods necessary to analyze and optimize supply chains w.r.t costs and environmental criteria.
To develop computer skills for supply chain calculations and visualising.
To write a well-documented report.
To present results in a clear and convincing way.

Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Data to be used (a.o. transport costs of containers from Asia to Europe) will be updated to today's situation. The outline of the course will remain the same. One or more papers to be studied will be changed.

course_title: Seminar The Economics of Exchange Rates
text:
Inhoud

This course concentrates on exchange-rate theory and policy. The seminar has five parts. It begins with a review of important concepts related to foreign exchange markets. This is followed by a discussion of different models of exchange rate determination and their policy implications. In the third part, we will discuss exchange market efficiency and the forecasting of exchange rates. The fourth part looks at what constitutes an optimal currency area and implications for the euro area. In the last part of the seminar, we will study the currency crises. Topics and emphasis may differ per semester, depending on the actuality.

Leerdoelen
  • Interpret important concepts in the economics of exchange rates
  • Understand the various models of exchange rates
  • Analyze real-world economic issues using the various models of exchange rates
  • Interpret academic papers
  • Conduct empirical research

Inhoud
  • General development of FinTech disruptions
  • Machine learning and credit default risk
  • Discrimination and technologies
  • Marketplace credit lending
  • Technology adoption on financial market
  • Digital banking
Leerdoelen

After completing this seminar, students can

  • gain immediate knowledge on the major financial innovations regarding their performance
  • learn about the first-order debates around such applications
  • evaluate FinTech disruptions both qualitatively and quantitatively
  • obtain basic skills in big data analysis, machine learning, and master thesis writing
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Course working load is going to be adjusted due to the reduction of seminar credit.
Potential updates on course literature can happen to maintain the content relevance. Extra The grade is based on group casework, research projects, and individual presentation, discussion participation, etc.
Test:​
Assignments, presentations, discussion, essays, ... (100%)

Inhoud

This seminar covers recent topics in International Trade. Among others, the following questions are explored: Can international trade help countries grow rich? Does international trade cause inequality? Who is for and against trade in politics, and why? Why do countries have trade surpluses/deficits, and to which extent are such imbalances problematic? What are the causes and effects of trade wars?
The seminar combines economic theory, quantitative empirical evidence, and historical case studies to throw light on these topics.

Leerdoelen

None

course_title: Seminar Urban, Port and Transport Economics
text:
Inhoud

In the seminar of major Urban, Port and Transport Economics, students analyze a spatial economic question. The seminar develops an economic location choice framework. Supplemented with spatial analysis (GIS) and empirical analysis of commuting (gravity equations), students simulate the spatial effects of a real-life economic scenario, such as the construction of new houses, new rail or road infrastructure, or structural economic change. An introduction to working with and visualizing spatial data is part of the course.

Leerdoelen
  • To define a problem and to use a coherent economic framework to address it
  • To analyze and visualize large data
  • To formulate advise based on economic research
  • To organise work and cooperate in a group.
Extra Final grade is a weighted average of individual (20%) and group assignments (80%).
The individually obtained grades must be sufficient (5.5 or higher).

course_title: Seminar in Business Analytics and Quantitative Marketing
lecturers: ['DJW Touw', 'dr. F Frasincar', 'dr. MH Akyuz', 'H Deng']
text:
Inhoud

Students are divided in small groups and each group tackles a different research question. The group performs the entire research process from start (formulating the exact research question) to end (presentation of results in the form of an academic paper and a presentation). Each group has weekly meetings with an academic supervisor to discuss ideas and progress.

Leerdoelen
  • Learn how to formulate a research question.
  • Learn how to translate research questions to quantitative modeling.
  • Learn how to apply quantitative models to data.
  • Learn how to translate model results to answers to research questions.
  • Apply quantitative techniques in a real-world setting.
  • Reporting academic research in a scientific article.
  • Reporting academic research in a presentation.
  • Work in a team.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar New research projects are defined each year, the overall setup of the seminar has stayed the same.

Inhoud

During this seminar groups of 3 or 4 students will try to answer a complex practical research question using econometric knowledge obtained during earlier courses. They have to report the results of the research in a scientific report and in a presentation.

Leerdoelen
  • The student learns how to formulate a proper research question with testable hypotheses.
  • The student learns to decide upon the correct data and appropriate econometric model to answer the research question.
  • The student learns how to do a research project in a team of four students.
  • The student learns to apply his econometric knowledge to do proper econometric inference.
  • The student learns to use estimation output resulting from an econometric analysis to answer the research question and to report his research in a scienfic report and a presentation.

lecturers: ['dr. SOR Lonn', "dr. TM Marreiros Bago d'Uva", 'J Klooster', 'KP de Wit, MSc', 'prof.dr. A Baillon', 'prof.dr. RL Lumsdaine', 'T van der Zwan, MSc']
text:
Inhoud

Students work in teams of 4 on specific (theoretical or empirical) financial econometric research projects. Examples include problems in asset pricing, portfolio management, risk management, and derivatives pricing.
Each team has its own supervisor. Teams meet with their supervisor on a weekly basis, to discuss the progress of the research and relevant issues and questions. Each team writes a report about its research. A plenary session is scheduled at the end of the course term, in which the research project is presented by a member of the team and discussed by a member of another team, followed by a plenary discussion.

Leerdoelen

Learn how to formulate a proper research question.
Learn to decide upon the appropriate econometric techniques to answer the research question.
Learn how to apply quantitative models to data.
Learn how to translate model results to answers to research questions.
Learn to report about the research project in the form of a (scientific) report and a presentation.
Learn to collaborate on a research project in a team with fellow students.

Inhoud

The choice of location can make or break a firm. Location is a fundamental condition for the success of a firm. The location of a firm can have a profound influence on its performance in terms of productivity, profit, or innovation. For example, the availability of a large pool of skilled labour or access to an excellent transport infrastructure may considerably enhance a firm’s productivity. Accordingly, firms are very selective when choosing a location. As a result, not all locations are suitable for all types of firm investments because they lack the appropriate specialised location advantages and for that reason economic activities tend to be very concentrated in space. At the same time, the requirements in terms of location also change as evidenced by the rise of high-tech clusters like Silicon Valley and Cambridge, and the concurrent decline of old industrial cities like Detroit and Manchester. Especially the advances in transport technology and ICT changed the required properties of location. Companies seem more foot-loose, and governments increasingly compete in attracting firms to their territory. Today, local and regional governments not only use subsidies and taxes but also capacity-building policies such as government spending on amenities, education, physical infrastructure, and public transportation networks to foster the attractiveness of their territory.

The aim of this seminar is to understand the location decisions of firms in general, and that of multinationals in particular. Most notably, attention will be paid to the empirics of multinational strategy and foreign direct investment. During the first half of the course, students are expected to present, discuss and evaluate recent articles related to the topic of the course. In the second half of the course, students have to conduct an empirical study in which they combine econometric techniques with theories on the importance of firm location.

Questions to be discussed in the above context are, for example:

  • Why do firms go to certain cities and clusters and not to others?
  • Why does a disproportionate number of firms end up in world cities like London, New York and Tokyo?
  • How can local authorities attract firms?
Leerdoelen

• Discuss and critically evaluate theories and empirical research on the location choice of firms.
• Think and act in an academic way on the interface of economics, business and geography.
• Conduct an empirical study on the location choice of firms using econometric techniques.

Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Guest lecture by IBM is back. New literature and new assignments.

lecturers: ['dr. MA Mankowski', 'dr. RM Badenbroek', 'prof.dr. APM Wagelmans']
text:
Inhoud

Solving a complex practical case.

Leerdoelen
  • To understand statistics, Linear programming, Combinatorial optimization, Markov Processes and/or Simulation.
  • For solving the case students have to perform statistical data analysis, use simulation and/or optimization software.
  • Students will practice presenting their results and summarizing them into a report.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Students will work on a case that is different from any case in previous years.

lecturers: ['dr. AS Bhaskarabhatla', 'dr. B Hoogendoorn', 'dr. SJA Hessels']
text:
Inhoud

Required literature (journal articles) will be announced during the seminar as part of the assignments. Students also have to search for literature themselves.

Leerdoelen

The “Seminar in Strategic Behaviour” is research-orientated and helps students to further develop and apply their skills for doing academic research in the field of Strategy Economics using quantitative empirical analysis. Students are divided into small groups and conduct three research related group assignments. Students also work on one assignment individually. The seminar provides students with insights into several timely topics in the field of Strategy Economics, and focusses on strategic behaviour for governments, firms, and individuals. Broad areas include among others competitive strategy, export strategy, and negotiation strategy.

Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Compared to the previous year, the structure of the course has been revised to reflect the reduction in ECTs from 12 to 10. Also, research proposal has been removed as one of the individual assignments because students simultaneously work on a thesis proposal for 2 ECTs.

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
lecturers: ['dr. M. Schonewille', 'E. Buitenhuis - Linssen', 'L.M.R. Nijs - de Langen']

course_title: Severe Mental Illness in Urban Context
college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['dr. FL Truijens', 'dr. JL Panman', 'S Nyapati, MSc']
text:
Inhoud IIn this course you will study severe mental illnesses such as psychotic spectrum disorders, and their comorbid conditions. In an urban context, severe mental problems not only go hand in hand with other unfavorable psychological conditions such as violence, substance use and dissociation but also require a different approach when it comes to diagnosis and treatment. People with chronic psychotic symptoms, whether or not in combination with several social problems such as homelessness and forensic problems, often require a more multidisciplinary approach in which not only their symptoms are treated but a case management approach with assertive outreach elements is needed.

In this course you will learn to identify severe mental illnesses and explore factors that are important for recovery. You learn to take a critical position regarding DSM-driven diagnosis and learn alternative diagnostical systems such as RDOC or holistic person-driven approaches. Information from previous courses will be integrated in this course and you will learn that severe mental illnesses are almost always combined with other disorders and/or severe social problems. You will learn appropriate treatment approaches for these problems (care vs. cure) and reflect on the ethical constrains of these approaches. Leerdoelen At the end of this course, the student knows how to
  1. Describe different models of psychopathology, treatment and recovery.
  2. Identify complex mental disorders and disabilities related to psychosis and ‘confused behavior’, especially within the urban context.
  3. Take a critical stance towards the use of the DSM and other diagnostic approaches in clinical practice and scientific research.
  4. Explain the value of multidisciplinary research and practice versus standardized approaches in working with severe mental illness.
  5. Reflect on his/her own role as a psychologist within a multidisciplinary team, including awareness of the ethical dimension of clinical practice.
Belangrijk om te weten Attendance is mandatory for three tutorial group meetings in weeks 2-4. Students are urged to attend the lectures before the tutorial group meetings.

Inhoud

De volgende simulatietechnieken worden behandeld:

  • Inleiding simulatiemodel
  • Vertalen complexe econometrische en besliskundige problemen in een simulatiemodel
  • Simulatiemodel validatie
  • Inleiding random generatoren
  • Methoden voor het genereren van realisaties van kansvariabelen
  • Discrete event simulatie
  • Monte Carlo methode
  • Statistische analyse van de uitkomsten van simulatie-experimenten
  • Simulatie optimalisatie

Let wel: Het hoorcollege zal in het Engels worden gegeven.

Leerdoelen
  • Het zelfstandig kunnen vertalen van complexe econometrische en besliskundige problemen in een simulatiemodel.
  • Het kunnen genereren van realisaties van kansvariabelen op een efficiënte manier.
  • Het kunnen interpreteren en bekritiseren van de resultaten van discrete event simulatie-experimenten.
  • Het kunnen implementeren van simulatiemodellen met gebruik van Java of Matlab.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar No major changes to the previous years besides a new instructor. The content of the course is also based on the previous year. The exam requirements and materials remain similar. We expect also two assignments, similarly to the previous editions.

Inhoud

The following simulation techniques will be covered:

  • Basic set-up of a Discrete-event simulation model
  • Formulating complex econometric and OR problems in a simulation model.
  • Model validation
  • Random number generators
  • Methods to generate realisations of random variables
  • Discrete event simulation
  • Monte Carlo method
  • Statistical analysis of simulation results.

.
  Leerdoelen
  • Being able to formulate independently a complex econometric / OR problem into a simulation model.
  • Generating realisation of random variables in an efficient way.
  • Interpreting and analyse outputs of discrete event simulation-experiments.
  • Being able to implement a simulation model using either Java or Matlab.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar No major changes to the previous years besides a new instructor. The content of the course is also based on the previous year. The exam requirements and materials remain similar. We expect also two assignments, similarly to the previous editions.

Inhoud
Instructor: 
prof. dr. B.F. Heidergott (VU), dr. A.A.N Ridder (VU)
 
Course content:
This course gives a broad treatment of the important aspects of Monte Carlo simulation and its applications in areas such as inventory control, project planning, reliability, risk analysis and financial models. The emphasis is on modeling the stochastic dynamic system as a discrete event system, and analyzing and improving its performance by means of discrete event simulation. The topics covered include generating random numbers, selecting input distributions and model validation. The course also teaches the statistical output analysis and the use of simulation in optimization and learning.
Leerdoelen After successful completion of this course, students will be able to:

Knowledge and Understanding:  Understand sampling random objects, discrete event simulation, simulation based sensitivity analysis, statistical output analysis.

Application of Knowledge: Model real-life problems by discrete-event models; conduct Montecarlo simulation-based analysis of a problem and provide an output analysis; apply simulation in optimization and learning.

Making judgement: Draw conclusions from simulation output.

Communication: Report on their findings from a simulation study.

course_title: Skills Workshop I: Scientific integrity, Transparent Algorithms, & Ethical Data Analysis
text:
Inhoud
Instructor: Peter Wakker (EUR).
 
Course content:
The skill workshop series enables students to fine-tune skills needed for a successful academic career. The series opens by tackling important issues related to the scientific integrity, transparent algorithm and ethical data management, which are highly relevant for a business data scientist. In the second year, practical aspects related to how to handle the review process, and grant applications will be discussed. In these workshops, writing and positioning skills are emphasized. The series closes with a workshop on presentation skills for research talks and conference presentations.
Leerdoelen This series of workshops have the primary objectives to:
  1. Provide students with a solid understanding of scientific integrity issues and ethical data management
  2. Understand and practice the review process, as author and reviewer
  3. Understand and practice the grant application process
  4. Fine-tune their academic presentation skills.
This course in particular has the primary objective to provide students with solid understanding of scientific integrity issues and ethical data management.

course_title: Skills Workshop II: The Review Process, Grants Applications, & Academic Presentations
text:
Inhoud Instructor: Benoit Crutzen (EUR), Francesca Sotgiu (VU).

 
Course content:
The skill workshop series enables students to fine-tune skills needed for a successful academic career. The series opens by tackling important issues related to the scientific integrity, transparent algorithm and ethical data management, which are highly relevant for a business data scientist. In the second year, practical aspects related to how to handle the review process, and grant applications will be discussed. In these workshops, writing and positioning skills are emphasized. The series closes with a workshop on presentation skills for research talks and conference presentations.
Leerdoelen This series of workshops have the primary objectives to:
  1. Understand and practice the review process, as author and reviewer
  2. Understand and practice the grant application process
  3. Fine-tune their academic presentation skills.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud
Contents, course description
Skill Seminars are training seminars in practical skills. They are essential to kick-starting an effective professional career and fundamental to adjusting easily to an international management environment.

Topics include:
  • Personal Development
  • Intercultural skills
  • Project Management
  • Group work skills
  • International negotiation techniques
  • Presentation skills
  • CV building and Job Application preparation
  • Business Communication

Small groups ensure an interactive dimension. Skill Seminars are offered by each CEMS member schools, very often in close cooperation with companies.

Students must accrue minimum four skills seminar days (2 EC) (1 day = 8 hours = 0.5 EC) over the duration of the programme in order to meet CEMS graduation requirements.
Leerdoelen
Learning Objectives

•    To gain practical experience in developing professional skills in a variety of business domains

Inhoud

The small business is the most common type of business in every modern economy, and it is not just a scaled-down version of a large business. The course 'Small Business Economics' is about the importance of small businesses and entrepreneurship for markets and economies. Amongst others, we discuss differences between small and large businesses, how small business ownership and entrepreneurship are related, how entrepreneurs exploit and deal with uncertainty, how small businesses contribute to economic growth, and how small businesses can attract finance. Lectures are organized around central questions (see the syllabus). During the course, two group assignments need to be completed on timely topics in the field of small business economics.

Leerdoelen
  • Introduction to the world of small business economics and the economics of entrepreneurship
  • Becoming familiar with the differences between small and large firms both from an external perspective (economy, market) and from an internal perspective (management, organisation)
  • Reflecting upon the impact of small businesses and entrepreneurship on economic development
  • Introduction to the specifics of small business finance
  • Applying theory to case studies
  • Mining publicly available data about small businesses and entrepreneurship for stylised facts using basic statistical tools
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar The course contents have been updated at various places to reflect the most recent small business economics trends.

college: Institute for Housing and Urban Development Studies (IHS)
lecturers: ['dr. CB Pennink', 'dr. S Pagliarin', 'EM Ensenado', 'JM Waardenburg']
text:
Inhoud
SMART cities use digital technology in combination with smart governance and smart people to better govern and develop cities. The use of smart technologies is growing in popularity, with many cities branding themselves as a “Smart City”. The use of technology is also of great interest to the private sector, who sees the opportunity to innovate and to have access to lucrative business opportunities. Research however shows that being a smart city does not always lead to inclusiveness and sustainable outcomes. Smart technologies may favour a small group, leading to increased inequality and exclusion. Also smart technologies may especially be used for economic purposes and less so for social or economic ones.  This course therefore raises the question how we can govern smart cities in such a way that they become more inclusive and sustainable.
After the module, participants should be able to (1) critically reflect on the different concepts underpinning Smart Cities, Inclusive Smart Cities and Sustainable Smart Cities; (2) appreciate the trends in and impacts of smart technologies on urban governance and development; and (3) assess different governance and project responses and their relevance for the development of smart, inclusive and sustainable cities.
  Leerdoelen After the module, participants should be able to (1) critically reflect on the different concepts underpinning Smart Cities, Inclusive Smart Cities and Sustainable Smart Cities; (2) appreciate the trends in and impacts of smart technologies on urban governance and development; and (3) assess different governance and project responses and their relevance for the development of smart, inclusive and sustainable cities.

course_title: Smart and Shared Cities: The world is changing and becoming "smart", but how do we ensure it is “SHARED”?
college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['A Psyllidis', 'AJ Klievink', 'dr. A Ersoy', 'dr. AR Ingrams', 'dr. JM Engelbert', 'dr.ir. EA Rijshouwer', 'E Eumann', 'EM Leclercq', 'K Kuribayashi', 'L Meilof', 'LS van Herwijnen', 'MJ Slotboom, MSc', 'prof.dr. EA van Zoonen', 'S Vydra']
text:
Inhoud

The minor SMART and SHARED Cities is a 15 EC and 30 EC minor programme combined. The student should choose the course load when registering for the minor. This is a full-time minor program – and participating in lectures and activities is mandatory.  

This minor is built on a combination of data, urban, political and social sciences. This multidisciplinary minor is open to all students who are interested in the development of smart and shared cities. The minor is offered in English and accessible for both national and international students. The format and modules include classic and innovative teaching methods, i.e. lectures and seminars, field trips, case-based group assignments, video production, blogging and logbooks and the integration of academia and practice. If necessary – all classes and activities will be online.

The program is characterized by a multi-disciplinary approach, which allows students to take different perspectives and understand the complexity of smart city life. The program intends to stimulate a reflective mindset, focusing on the interrelation of problems and responsible innovation. The learning goals concern knowledge, attitude and skills which in combination need to equip students with a critical mindset that enables them to work towards public needs and interests in smart cities.

Knowledge: Upon completion of the minor, the student will know what a smart city is and how the associated definitions and discourses produce a particular technological and data practice in which particular concerns and interests take privilege over others. S/he will also understand the kind of participatory spaces that are created by and for citizens, and the competing governance models that smart cities advocate. The student will also have a basic insight in the various data and analytics that are relevant to the development of smart cities.

Attitude: Students will develop a critical but constructive attitude towards different views and opinions about the smart city. They will value the contrasting perspectives of private and public stakeholders and will be able to adapt to and explain different views, suggest different solutions and prioritize advices based on different cases with different values. The core ethos of the minor concerns, however, public values in the smart cities, which are encapsulated in the SHARED principles and ethics that underlie various Dutch digital agendas and have been adopted by the VSNU.

Skills: Upon completion of the minor, students will be able to recognize particular interests and values in smart city discourse and practice; they will be able to choose appropriate data for specific urban challenges (critical thinking and information literacy); they will be able to work in multidisciplinary and trans-sectoral teams and adapt to particular team requirements and collaborative styles (collaboration and communication). For the 30 EC minor, an additional set of skills (e.g. Initiative and technology literacy) will be acquired through internships and projects in the research labs.


Special aspects:

Since this is a Leiden-Delft-Erasmus minor, the location of where education is offered difference per module. The minor takes place at Erasmus University, TU Delft and Leiden University. This minor is a full-time programme. Therefore it is not possible to combine this minor program with other extra-curricular activities.

It is possible for Erasmus students to complete the minor for 15 EC (modules 1, 2 and 3). EUR students can also choose to complete the minor as a whole for 30 EC. The extra 15 EC is extra-curricular. To include the extra 15 EC in your Bachelor program, EUR students need to ask permission from their Exam Board.

Deficiencies of students’ knowledge will be tackled at the beginning of each module. Each module will begin with an online quiz that will provide the student with a list of material for self-study to align the knowledge base of students from the various disciplines. All modules will be given in a blended form, i.e. partly face-to-face (e.g. lectures) and partly online (e.g. video’s, web lectures, online documents).

This program is specially developed for students from Leiden University, Delft University of Technology and Erasmus University Rotterdam. The purpose of this minor programme is to educate professionals from different fields such social, economic, environmental engineering and political science on the importance of the different aspects in the use of Big, Open and Linked Data within creating the smart and shared city.

A point of attention regarding the different students and the diversity in study background, as this means that students will most likely have different entry levels. This is considered while designing the programme and the prerequisites to participate. By blending education and using online and offline tools, teachers can check the levels of knowledge of the students upon entry of the course and eventually supply them with relevant background materials to get up to speed.

For this minor there is a balance between traditional and innovative learning methods. The modules are designed in a blended learning form, meaning lectures will make use of face-to-face lectures, online documents and articles, and video’s/online lectures. Reading materials include policy papers, reports, articles and books. We will use Canvas as the electronic teaching environment.


Module 1: Introduction to the smart city

  • 5 EC
  • Faculty: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences, Erasmus University
  • Content: In this first module the students will be introduced to the core ideas of the smart city and technologies. The module will cover various smart city concepts and address the basic digital and data technologies (key enabling technologies) that constitute smart cities. There will also be ample attention for the legal, ethical, political and social dilemmas in smart cities. 
    • Week 1    What is a smart city and which economic and social actors make it?
    • Week 2    How is the smart city connected to economic and political power? 
    • Week 3    Which democratic and ethical control is needed in and for the smart city?
  • Teaching method(s): reading, guest lecture, field trip and video.
  • Teaching materials: scientific and professional papers and teaching cases, to be provided or indicated via the syllabus for the minor.
  • Contact hours: 10 per week (hours may differ)     
Module 2: Citizens and everyday experiences with the smart city
  • 5 EC
  • Faculty: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences, Erasmus University
  • Content: Many of the smart city projects are framed as producing solutions to large challenges in cities, regarding, among others, the environment, mobility, security and safety. In this module we approach the smart city from the perspective of the citizen and the social fabric in the city. Who benefits from smart city developments, whose interests are served? Which groups miss out, and how is everyday life in streets, stores, pubs and clubs affected?
    • Week 1    How do citizens participate in urban development, planning, governance and local democracy?
    • Week 2    How do digitization and data play a role in how citizens participate in urban
      development, planning, governance and democracy?
    • Week 3    How can we apply data and empowerment-examples and theory to support citizens to participate in urban development, planning, governance and democracy?
  • Teaching method(s): online reading, documentary, response lecture, research presentation and living lab.
  • Teaching materials: scientific and professional papers and teaching cases, to be provided or indicated via the syllabus for the minor.
  • Contact hours: 10 per week (hours may differ)
Module 3: Governing the smart city
  • 5 EC
  • Faculty: Faculty Governance and Global Affairs, Leiden University
  • Content: Data and digital technologies offer both great potential for cities and great risks. In this module we discuss the effects of platform capital in cities, in the form of, among others, AirBnB and Uber. We explore the various responses from banning (as in Barcelona) to regulating (as in Amsterdam) and free entry (as in many other cities in the world). We will show the political-economic interests of these platforms and discuss the European regulations and attempts at curtailing them. We also zoom in on the way cities themselves explore the use of digital and data technologies and which models of regulation and participation they have developed. The module will have a strong public input from public administration perspectives and discuss how different governance ideologies (new public management vs new public service) produce different understandings of what a smart city should achieve. 
  • Learning objectives:
    • Understand the playing field of smart cities with the use of conceptual models;
    • Understand the consequences of the complexity of smart city playing fields for the
    governing of the smart city;
    • Design instruments/strategies for interactive governance of the smart city.
  • Teaching method(s): reading, online lecture, guest lecture, online library / toolkit and groupwork.
  • Teaching materials: Scientific and professional papers and teaching cases, to be provided or indicated via the syllabus for the minor.
  • Contact hours: 10 per week (hours may differ)  

Overview content per week:

Week 1-3    Introduction to the smart city - Classes on Monday, Wednesday and Friday. Self-study on Tuesday and Thursday.
Week 4-6    Citizens and everyday experiences with the smart city - Classes on Monday, Wednesday and Friday. Self-study on Tuesday and Thursday.
Week 7-9    Governing the smart city - Classes on Monday, Wednesday and Friday. Self-study on Tuesday and Thursday.
Week 10     Module 1, 2 and 3 - Resit
                   

How do you get your grade for the minor?

Each module has a number of graded assignments. You will get specific instructions in each module.
The grade for each modules is based on a bespoke calculation that may differ per module.
All assignments will be handed in through Canvas, under heading ‘Assignment’.
You need to pass every module, the average of three modules is your final grade

Module 1:

  • You have various mandatory activities and three graded assignments, one per week;
  • All mandatory activities have to be finished and handed in before the set deadline;
  • Each graded assignment counts for 33%.

Module 2:
  • Complete 3 group assignments (pass/fail);
  • 1 individual Assignment (for a grade).

Module 3:
  • An individual final paper based on weekly journal entries;
  • A group presentation book on a multistakeholder governance challenge;
  • An individual reflection on the groupwork;
  • A group video showcasing the presentation book.

No final marks are given between 5.0 and 6.0 and the following rounding rules are used: a 5.5 or higher is rounded to 6.0 and a 5.49 or lower is rounded to 5.0; Outside the 5.0 - 6.0 range, final marks are expressed as a number with one decimal.

Students need to pass each module with a grade of at least 5.5 (there is no compensation) in order to complete the minor.
Each module will have its own grade composition which will be described in the syllabus for the minor.

Essays with corrections and feedback will be returned to the students. There will be a feedback moment after each of the assignments.
The lecturer provides written or oral feedback on the individual assignment and the group assignment.

Leerdoelen For students completing this minor, there are generic competences and specific competences to be acquired. The minor programme mainly focuses on skills such as analysing and evaluating (policies/strategies). After completing block A (15 EC programme), students will have acquired specific knowledge on smart cities and how data usage could be optimized for its citizens and civil servants. 

Module 1. Introduction to the smart city (5 EC)
After this module students are able to:
•                 Explain the origins and functions of the smart city concept;
•                 Identify enabling technologies and methodologies of the smart city;
•                 Identify (recognize) and compare the different conceptions of the smart city concept;
•                 Position him/herself in the smart city debate, argue for that position and reflect on that position.

Module 2. Citizens and everyday experiences with the smart city (5 EC)
After this module students are able to:
•                 Understand the digital & social division in society;
•                 Explain how citizens can take role in city dynamics;
•                 Evaluate tools that mobilize groups of citizens.

Module 3. Governing the smart city (5 EC)
After this module students are able to:
•                 Understand the playing field of smart cities with the use of conceptual models;
•                 Understand the consequences of the complexity of smart city playing fields for the governing of the smart city;
•                 Design instruments/strategies for interactive governance of the smart city.

    governing of the smart city;
