college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. LSG Ried, MSc', 'dr. M Stevens', 'dr. TC Berends', 'EJ Haag, MSc', 'prof.dr. JYF Wynstra']
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
Over the past two decades, purchasing and supply management (PSM) has evolved from a clerical function focused on buying goods and services at a minimum price into a strategic function focused on value creation and achieving competitive advantage. Many manufacturing and service firms realize that PSM does not only impact financial performance, but also other aspects such as innovation and environmental performance. In this respect, firms need to consider not only the day-to-day operations of PSM, but also more value adding and strategic issues. They need to address make or buy decisions, sourcing strategies, organisation of the supply base, supplier performance management, sustainability, and supply risk management. In this elective course, we build on and extend the knowledge of the core course Purchasing (BM05SCM), and prepare students for their future career in purchasing by involving them in PSM-related projects of companies.   Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
The objective of this elective course is to provide students with the key concepts regarding ‘strategic’ and ‘value-adding’ aspects of purchasing and supply management. The course covers manufacturing as well as service industries, and looks at sourcing of both products and services. One of the key objectives is to enable the students to establish the theory-practice link by working on practical purchasing and supply management projects with companies. Upon completing this course students can: 
  • Understand the value various sourcing activities can add to organizations.  
  • Understand how Purchasing and Supply Management (PSM) strategy aligns with business strategy and how this impacts the organisation of PSM.  
  • Evaluate how various supplier relationship management strategies can be applied in different sourcing situations. 
  • Evaluate which type of contract is to be used to effectively source products and services. 
  • Evaluate which risk management strategy to use in a variety of sourcing arrangements. 
  • Create a solution for a sourcing problem.  

Many of the students who have followed this course subsequently pursue a career in purchasing and supply management, or supply chain management, but in today’s current business environment the course will be of benefit to you also when you plan to pursue a career, for example, in general management, marketing, business development or innovation and product management.

college: Institute for Housing and Urban Development Studies (IHS)
lecturers: ['D Schelkshorn, MSc', 'dipl.-ing. EP Petsani', 'dr. A Baliga', 'dr. AR Jachnow', 'dr. MMJ van Eerd', 'dr. NB Sakizlioglu Uitermark', 'dr.ing. AA Ayala Aleman', 'E Makousiari, MSc']
text:
Inhoud
The SUPP course links theory and practice by introducing theoretical knowledge on strategic planning, planning and complexity, self-organisation, informality, urban justice, and applying tools and methods employed in planning practice, such as serious gaming and stakeholder negotiation. Participants will use this knowledge and develop their skills through a real case study by engaging with stakeholders in a planning process.
At the beginning of the course, the focus is on building theoretical knowledge on urban planning and acquiring spatial and social analysis skills. Following that, the specialisation focuses on engaging with stakeholders from different cities (and countries) to develop a series of planning outputs that give insights into the city’s socio-spatial dynamics and allow participants to discuss different strategies for the future.  During this interactive and co-creative planning process, the participants will employ different innovative methodologies such as serious games. At the end of the course, the participants will present and reflect on the planning outcomes and processes during a final workshop with urban stakeholders organised by the participants. In the last weeks of the course, the participants will work on an individual academic paper that brings together all the course learning.

Week 1 Introduction and Planning Theory
During the first week, participants will acquire knowledge of planning theory. We will discuss urban planning trends, paradigms, and approaches, and issues like complexity, systems thinking and scale, social and spatial innovation, governance, and urbanisation concerning urban planning.

Week 2 Planning Cycle and Development of Socio-Spatial Skills
The participants will develop their socio-spatial analytical skills in the second week through workshops about socio-spatial analysis and visualisation, and urban observation. At the end of this first week, the participants will present a socio-spatial analysis of selected areas. During this week, we will also discuss strategic planning and the steps of the planning cycle.

Week 3 Urban Justice
In the third week, we will discuss urban justice theory through a series of lectures that addresses topics such as social justice, inequality, spatial justice, gentrification, counter-hegemonic trends, gender, and adequate housing. The participants will learn to reflect on the normative dimension of urban planning and why this academic and professional field is concerned with urban justice.
 
Week 4 Stakeholder Engagement
Urban planning is approached in the specialisation as a multi-stakeholder activity. Therefore, during the fourth week, participants will discuss participatory planning and empowerment theories and reflect on the modalities, processes, and challenges of public participation. They will identify and profile relevant stakeholders for the group work and prepare a strategy to facilitate a process of negotiated planning.
 
Week 5 Gaming for Urban Planning
This week, the participants will learn game thinking principles and co-design a game for stakeholder engagement. The week comprises workshops, lectures, and progress meetings that support the game development.
 
Week 6 Urban Policy Design and Analysis
At the beginning of week 6, the participants will develop an urban vision for selected areas with stakeholders. Following this, the participants will learn about urban policy design and analysis. We will discuss the different stages of policymaking and reflect on the qualities of urban public policies, the interests, values, and their impact on existing dynamics. The participants will also learn about tools for policy analysis.

Week 7 Strategies Development
During week 7, the participants will focus on the group work’s assignment. The game will be played with invited peers to formulate strategies and policy recommendations for the selected areas.

Week 8 Group Work Presentation and Individual Academic Paper
The participants will present the outcome of the group work to the stakeholders, reflect on the planning process and the use the gaming for urban planning and stakeholder engagement. Afterwards, the participants will work on their academic paper assignment.

Week 9 Individual Academic Paper and Course Evaluation
This week is for working on the academic paper assignment and final course evaluation.
 
Leerdoelen The overall learning objective of the course is to engage in reflective practice regarding urban planning and governance and its influence on socio-spatial dynamics.
Throughout this course, the participants will:
  • Develop a future-oriented and multi-stakeholder approach to inclusive and sustainable urban development.
  • Become aware of the value dimension and ethical implications of planning.
  • Develop their identity as urban planners and managers.
After completing the course, participants should be able to:
  • Explain the concepts and principles of strategic planning, participatory planning and co-creation, gender sensitive-planning, and sustainable urban development.
  • Critically discuss planning theory, principles, and values applying interdisciplinary lenses.
  • Develop a theoretical urban planning framework with a focus on sustainability and justice principles.
  • Apply planning concepts, tools, methodologies, and theoretical frameworks to:
  • Analyse the socio-spatial dynamics and emerging issues in cities concerning complex urban problems for different scale levels.
  • Critically assess plans, planning initiatives, and policies from socio-spatial perspectives, their interrelations, and their impact on existing urban dynamics.
  • Assess stakeholders’ mandates, motivations, behaviours, and actions as determined by urban and planning policies.
  • Formulate a strategy to engage with different stakeholders throughout the whole planning cycle.
  • Facilitate a process of negotiated planning among several stakeholders.
  • Propose planning strategies (including programs and projects), policies and visions that: a) integrate social, environmental, economic, spatial, and institutional components to guide sustainable urban development; b) deal with complex urban problems, contemporary multicultural societies needs and multidisciplinary settings; c) are based on sustainability and justice principles.
  • Formulate recommendations for urban planning practice.
  • Convincingly communicate ideas and arguments about planning orally, visually, and in writing with various audiences.

course_title: Strategic formulation, entrepreneurship and the political environment
college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
The course will help students explore and better understand how politics and their environments both internally to the enterprise and externally affect strategy formulation with a specific focus on emerging economies
This module will allow the student to be able to analyze of the inter-related nature of the environment in which business organizations exist and the implications for the way they work.  An introduction to models of industry analysis. An introduction to the main theoretical planning models.  The use and application of financial information relevant to different groups of stakeholders.  The implications and influence of cultural and ethical issues for strategic planning.  The effective strategies for organizational competition and growth.
The course will include but not be limited to explore Micro-politics, concepts on national, regional and local identifies. The impact of local networks and political capital, Multinationals versus local in contextualization and influencing laws and regulations. The impact of international politics and local enterprises: trade wars, climate change, regional alliances, trade zones, international agreements, WTO. The politics and strategy development of globalization vs localization in emerging nations. Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
  1. To allow the student to analyze and explain the benefits to organizations, and in particular small and medium enterprises, of strategic planning within the business environment and employ specific techniques, methods and models used in the assessment and evaluation of a given organization’s strategy development when taking into account the political environment.
  2. Analyze the external environment, and in particular, political networks and practices, in which organizations exist and its effects on strategic planning paying particular attention the effect these may have on industries or sectors in emerging economies.
  3. Tabulate and analyze the relative strengths and weaknesses of a given business organization and its ability to influence these environments; and identify and evaluate the appropriate strategic choices for a given organization within an economic and political context.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. EJ Klitsie', 'dr. X Welch Guerra, MSc']
text:
Inhoud

Contents, course description

The core element of this course are your consultancy projects. You will start off working in small groups on a field project of your own choice, analyzing the strategic problem or opportunity of your client and developing strategic solutions.  During this project you will be coached by the lecturers, who will provide you detailed feedback. As a major milestone of your project you have the opportunity to present and discuss your intermediate findings in front of a panel consisting of your coach and representatives of a top tier strategy consulting firm. 

The consultancy project is complemented by a series of lectures and workshops, where you present and discuss case assignments and sharpen your analytical skills. These sessions will be hosted by your lecturers, as well as guest lectures from different management consulting firms or inhouse consulting departments of large multinationals. Our interactive lectures and workshops develop your understanding of strategy consulting in a broader context, from both academic as well as practical perspectives. 

Format
The course is structured into four workshop days consisting of case discussions, interactive (guest) lectures, project coaching and a milestone presentation of your group project.

Grading
The course does not contain an exam. Instead, grading is based on the group project (40%) and individual grade components (60%)

Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
This course centers on real consultancy projects, coached by the lecturers and our renowned consulting partners. After completing this course, students should be able to:
  • identify a client’s strategic issue
  • develop and structure effective strategies to solve such issues
  • present findings in a clear and coherent manner
  • convince top managers and other important stakeholders of your conclusions
  • understand the history, structure, and working processes of the consulting industry

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['AL van Zijl, MSc', 'dr. B Vermeeren', 'dr. NJL Cannaerts', 'prof.dr. L den Dulk']
text:
Inhoud In het vak Strategisch Human Resource Management (SHRM) wordt ingegaan op de strategische inzet van arbeid in publieke organisaties. Hierbij staat de afstemming tussen het HR-beleid en de organisatiestrategie centraal. Deze afstemming is een voortdurend proces, waarbij zowel aanpassingen in de organisatie als in het personeelsinstrumentarium nodig zijn om op de lange termijn een bijdrage aan de organisatieprestaties te kunnen leveren. Vanuit de diverse strategische benaderingen in de HRM literatuur wordt het afstemmingsproces in publieke organisaties benaderd, waarbij actuele ontwikkelingen in de omgeving van deze organisaties een bepalende rol spelen. Het vak SHRM bouwt voort op basiskennis over HRM, zoals in Werken in de Publieke Sector (B3) aan de orde is gekomen. Verder biedt het vak een raamwerk waarop in de MHRV vakken Verandermanagement en HRM in de Publieke Sector wordt voortgebouwd.
 
  Leerdoelen Na afloop van de cursus is de student in staat om:
  • te beschrijven wat de kernbenaderingen binnen het veld van Strategisch Human Resource Management (SHRM) zijn;
  • te beredeneren welke theorieën en concepten bij de verschillende benaderingen van SHRM horen;
  • uit te leggen wat de relatie is tussen ontwikkelingen in de omgeving van publieke organisaties en het SHRM van deze organisaties;
  • uit te leggen onder welke voorwaarden SHRM bijdraagt aan de prestaties van publieke organisaties;
  • onderzoek op het terrein van SHRM te beoordelen op wetenschappelijke kwaliteit en toepasbaarheid voor de praktijk.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud In dit vak voer je een strategische analyse uit en geef je advies aan een bestaand bedrijf. Je doet dit in teams van vijf studenten. Je zult meerdere keren op bedrijfsbezoek gaan, op zoek gaan naar informatie over de markt en omgeving van het bedrijf, en uiteindelijk een goed onderbouwd en praktisch relevant rapport inleveren - bij de universiteit, maar ook bij het bedrijf zelf.

Veel studenten kijken terug op SBP als een van de leukste en meest uitdagende ervaringen tijdens hun opleiding. Je doet praktijkervaring op in strategisch advies, je kunt de vaardigheden toepassen die je tijdens het eerste jaar hebt opgedaan en je krijgt waardevol inzicht in hoe bedrijven echt 'werken'. Helaas is SBP voor sommige studenten juist een heel frustrerende ervaring, omdat ze ontdekken hoe moeilijk het kan zijn om met teamleden en bedrijven samen te werken. De beste tip die we je kunnen geven om optimaal van dit vak te profiteren, is binnen je team duidelijke regels en afspraken te maken en op tijd op zoek te gaan naar een interessant bedrijf dat graag met jullie wil samenwerken

Studenten moeten daarom tijdens blok 2 en voordat ze met het vak beginnen, twee Qualifying Assignments uitvoeren: Teamformatie en Bedrijfsregistratie. Je moet hiervoor een team van vijf studenten samenstellen, een teamcontract opstellen, en een bedrijf vinden dat met jullie wil samenwerken. Bedrijven moeten aan bepaalde criteria voldoen om geschikt te worden gevonden. Studenten die deze assignments niet uitvoeren, kunnen niet aan het vak deelnemen. Tijdens twee hoorcolleges in blok 2 worden deze assignments aangekondigd en toegelicht. De inschrijving voor het team verloopt via SIN-Online en is mogelijk vanaf 27 oktober t/m 15 november.

In blok 3 en 4 voer je met je team vier opdrachten uit. Via kennisclips zul je instructies en tips krijgen over de inhoud van deze opdrachten. Vóór de deadlines van de opdrachten krijg je de mogelijkheid je tutor te spreken tijdens een vragenuurtje. Als de opdrachten ingeleverd zijn, worden ze in werkgroepen gepresenteerd en bediscussieerd. Je ontvangt van je tutor ook schriftelijke feedback op de opdrachten. Dee schriftelijke feedback moet je gebruiken om de inhoud te verbeteren.

De inhoud van deze opdrachten vormt de basis van je eindrapport, dat je tegen het einde van het studiejaar inlevert.

  Leerdoelen
  • toepassen van vaardigheden in teamwerk, inclusief het maken van een ‘Team Contract’ en daarin vastgelegde afspraken en regels naleven.
  • toepassen van vaardigheden in projectmanagement, inclusief tijdsmanagement en planning.
  • toepassen van vaardigheden in schrijven, presenteren en argumenteren.
  • logisch en consistent toepassen van een beperkt aantal strategische concepten en tools op een bestaand bedrijf.
  • begrijpen van beperkingen en toepasbaarheid van verschillende databronnen voor verschillende analyses.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud De mondialisering van markten, snelle technologische ontwikkelingen, kortere productlevenscycli en toenemende agressiviteit van concurrenten hebben de basisregels van de concurrentiestrijd in de 21e eeuw ingrijpend gewijzigd. Deze verhevigde concurrentiekrachten dwingen bedrijven om zich sneller te vernieuwen dan voorheen. Het tegelijkertijd oog hebben voor innovatie en de effectiviteit van de dagelijkse werkzaamheden blijkt echter één van de grootste obstakels van het management te zijn. Strategisch management wordt hierdoor gezien als één van belangrijkste activiteiten en uitdagingen voor hedendaagse organisaties.

Succesvolle organisaties van de afgelopen decennia zijn in staat geweest om adequaat te reageren op omgevingsveranderingen. Niet alleen door producten en diensten te ontwikkelen die aansluiten bij de klantwensen, maar juist door vooruit te denken en ontwikkelingen in gang te zetten die zorgen voor een duurzame voorsprong. Deze voorsprong komt voort uit het creëren van nieuwe kennis en het toepassen daarvan in nieuwe bedrijfsprocessen. Niet alleen de strategievorming, maar ook de manier waarop strategische veranderingen worden geïmplementeerd spelen daarbij een belangrijke rol.

Strategisch management gaat dan ook verder dan het analyseren van de interne mogelijkheden en de externe veranderingen: het omvat zowel het bedenken en aansturen van nieuwe initiatieven binnen organisaties, maar ook het ontwerpen van effectieve management- en organisatieprocessen, organisatiestructuren, en samenwerkingsverbanden. Voorbeelden zoals IKEA, Dell, TomTom en Ryanair zetten ons op het spoor van vernieuwend leiderschap en het ontwikkelen en toepassen van nieuwe kennis en vaardigheden. Zo leidde Dell’s vooruitziende blik van directe levering zonder intermediairs in de pc-markt tot een nieuw succesvol bedrijfsmodel. Ikea’s baanbrekende idee van directe levering en zelfassemblage door consumenten in de meubelindustrie betekende een einde aan de gemiddeld 4 maanden levertijd in het lagere prijssegment. Ook TomTom’s visie op navigatiesystemen voor de tweedehandsmarkt van bestaande auto’s en Ryanair’s notie van efficiency en procesvernieuwing hebben vergaande implicaties gehad voor de navigatie en communicatie- en luchtvaartindustrie.

Tijdens het vak Strategisch management wordt stilgestaan bij de belangrijkste vraagstukken van organisaties in een sterk veranderende internationale omgeving. Succesvolle en minder succesvolle organisaties worden uitgelicht en onderwerpen met versterkte relevantie in de moderne context komen tijdens de verschillende colleges aan bod.
  Leerdoelen Door het volgen van Strategisch Management leren studenten om…
  1. … hun strategische inzicht te vergroten om te verklaren hoe achterliggende factoren ervoor zorgen dat organisaties een duurzaam concurrentievoordeel kunnen behalen
  2. … de verscheidene facetten te analyseren die binnen organisaties en bedrijfsomgevingen van belang zijn voor strategisch management
  3. … uit verschillende strategische modellen te kiezen in het evalueren van organisaties
  4. … deze strategische inzichten toe te passen om het ontwikkelingstraject van organisaties te voorspellen
  5. … de concepten en methodieken die aan strategisch management ten grondslag liggen te beschrijven vanuit een wetenschappelijk gefundeerde basis.

Inhoud

Business strategy is a field of study concerned with developing the understanding of why some firms are more successful than others. To succeed, managers must develop the resources and capabilities needed to gain and sustain advantage in competitive markets—traditional and emerging. The way in which organisations attempt to develop such competitive advantage constitutes the essence of their strategy. This course introduces the concept of strategic management through readings, discussion and case analyses, and considers the basic direction and goals of an organisation, the environment (social, political, technological, economic and global factors), industry and market structure, and organisational strengths and weaknesses. The emphasis is on the development and successful implementation of strategy in different types of firms across industries.
The class is structured with (guest) lectures to present theoretical concepts and how those apply in practice. The PBL sessions as well as the strategic case analysis and written report ensure that students understand and apply the concepts during each class session.

Leerdoelen
  • Define and understand the concept of strategy
  • Identify and evaluate the key strategic choices available to organizations
  • Demonstrate and raise awareness of the main issues involved in managing strategically
  • Understand and apply relevant theoretical concepts and frameworks of strategic management to organizations
  • To apply the knowledge obtained through this course to diagnose the reasons for good or bad performance and make recommendations on how improvements can be realized

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. EJ Klitsie', 'dr. MG Baaij', 'dr. X Welch Guerra, MSc']
text:
Inhoud
Questions that you may have;
  • Can I learn the structured problem-solving method, tools and techniques of the world’s best strategy consulting firms?
  • Is a career in strategy consulting something for me?
  • What is important to know when working for a strategy consulting firm?

To help you, this Minor course provides you with a practical multi-level introduction to strategy consulting. We will teach you;
  1. the structured problem-solving method, tools and techniques of the world’s best strategy consulting firms
  2. tools and theories for understanding of:
    1. strategy consulting projects,
    2. strategy consulting firms
    3. and the strategy consulting industry  

This minor combines (online) classroom (case) workshops and consulting projects.
 
  • In the workshops you will present and discuss real world strategy consultancy cases and other relevant topics. Moreover, you will work on consultancy case assignments (among others, with coaching by guests from strategy consulting firms).
  • In a field consulting project, you will work with a group of fellow students (of your own choice) on an actual real-world consultancy case for a client in the profit or not-for-profit sector.
  • Additionally, you will further develop your consulting skills by performing a desk consulting project.
This minor is relevant for you if you are considering a career in (strategy) consulting, but you will also benefit from your new knowledge and skills if you pursue other careers.  Alumni of the course regularly let us know how it has benefited their careers. Some are consultants but many are also still using the learned techniques in their non-consulting related jobs. We hope that you will join them.
Leerdoelen

After successfully completing this minor, you can:
  • Apply the methods and techniques of the world’s best strategy consulting firms on a real-world project
    • Identify the real strategic issues of your clients: both problems and opportunities
    • Structure and analyze these issues to develop valuable new insights
    • Develop hypotheses about potential strategies for effectively addressing these issues
    • Collect and analyze data to test your hypotheses to get confidence in your strategy
    • Create high-impact recommendations with convincing argumentation to get clients to accept your advice
    • Translate your advice to practical roadmaps for execution
  • Assess and manage the relationship with your client and engage other stakeholders to be more effective and get support for your advice
  • Assess strategies and business models of strategy consulting firms to understand the important differences
  • Evaluate competitive developments in the strategy consulting industry to see where the industry is going
  • Reflect on a real live strategy consultancy experience to find out whether consulting is something for you

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
Questions that will be covered in the course are:
  • What are the distinct characteristics of platforms and markets with network effects?
  • Why do some platforms become dominant, while others remain in their niche status?
  • What are important strategies for firms in platform markets?
  • How is pricing in platform markets distinct from pricing in traditional markets?
  • How do platforms attract and manage producers of complementary products?
  • Why are standards so important in platform markets and how do firms compete in standards battles?
  • How to regulate and conduct public policy in platform markets?
The course will connect the knowledge that students have gained in their core courses such as Information Strategy or undergraduate courses on strategy and digital economics to a more advanced and rigorous knowledge of the relevant concepts in platform markets.  Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
Many of the most successful companies of the digital age such as Google, Facebook, Apple, Microsoft or Amazon can be characterized as platforms. A platform connects distinct user groups, thereby creating value by enabling interactions between these groups. They are governed by market forces such as network effects that are distinct from traditional markets and therefore have attracted the attention of scholars in strategy and economics, but also policy makers and business gurus.

The goal of this course is to introduce students to current research on platforms from the fields of strategy and economics and apply it to management and public policy related questions on platform markets.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. HJD Klapper', 'dr. TH van Balen, MPhil']
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
Whether an organization innovates determines whether it survives. It does not take a world-wide crisis for an organization to realize that the status quo will not be sufficient. And it is not only the multi-national corporations like Amazon that need to innovate, it is the restaurant at the corner, the local charity, and even national governments see the need for innovation. The question is not whether to innovate, but how.  

In this course you learn why organizations struggle to innovate and what to do about it. The course is organized around three broad questions such that each question will be addressed in a specific module:  

1. How can organizations generate value?  

2. How can organizations capture the value that they generate? 

3. How can organizations and managers deliver value? 


Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
At the end of this course, students will be able to: 
  • Analyze an organization’s innovation strategy.
  • Interpret the potential and implication of innovations for an organization and environment. 
  • Craft strategic responses to innovations.  
  • Develop strategies to protect intellectual property.  
  • Plan and prepare for future scenarios.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:

course_title: Structuur en financiering van de gezondheidszorg
college: Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management
text:
Inhoud Met het vak Structuur en Financiering van de Gezondheidszorg (SFG) wordt kennis en inzicht verschaft in de organisatiestructuur en de financiering van de Nederlandse gezondheidszorg.

In een vijftal colleges/Q&A-sessies, ondersteund door online kennisclips, wordt achtereenvolgens ingegaan op de historische ontwikkeling van het Nederlandse zorgstelsel, de noodzaak tot uitgavenbeheersing in het licht van de collectieve financiering van zorg, de invoering van gereguleerde marktwerking in de curatieve zorg en de organisatie, financiering en recente hervorming van de langdurige zorg.
  Leerdoelen
  1. De student kan de hoofdlijnen van de huidige structuur en financiering van de Nederlandse gezondheidszorg weergeven en interpreteren.
  2. De student kan de historische ontwikkeling van het zorgstelsel in de afgelopen eeuw interpreteren en plaatsen in internationaal perspectief.
  3. De student kan de noodzaak tot beheersing van de zorguitgaven uitleggen in het licht van de collectieve zorgfinanciering.
  4. De student kan de logica en sterke en zwakke kanten van het stelsel van gereguleerde marktwerking in de curatieve zorg uitleggen en interpreteren.
  5. De student kan de redenen aangeven voor de hervorming van de langdurige zorg en een beargumenteerd oordeel geven over de sterke en zwakke kanten van deze hervorming.

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)

text:
Inhoud Learning is good, experiencing is better. This course, focused on Iran, adopts a project-based learning approach based on the principle of reciprocity. The main objective of this course is for students to gain field-based knowledge. Dutch students stand to deepen their knowledge about state and society in the Middle East in general and in Iran in particular. Iranian students will enhance their understanding about governance of the European Union in general and The Netherlands in particular. Both EUC students and their Iranian counterparts will increase knowledge on their respective home society by explaining its distinctive features to their peers. The course consists of three components. First, a series of preparatory meetings at EUC. Second, an outgoing mobility whereby an EUC delegation of approximately 15 students and staff will visit Iran under guidance of Iranian students. Third, an incoming mobility whereby an Iranian delegation visits The Netherlands guided by EUC students. Full participation in all components is mandatory for all course participants. Assignments will consist of practicing cross-cultural understanding through teamwork and small-scale diplomacy.
CAVEATS: 105 EUC Course Catalogue 2019-2020 September 2019
1/ THIS COURSE IS SUBJECT TO APPROVAL OF EXTERNAL PARTNERS, IT CAN BE CANCELLED AT ALL TIMES
2/ Be aware that the actual implementation of this course is not yet guaranteed. Several circumstances (logistics, international politics, enrollment,…) can alter the preferred course of action. In a worst-case scenario, an alternative course programme will be set up to ensure students can validate their credits. Students are only expected to cover flight tickets (approx. 500 EUR) by their own means. Limited funding may be available for strong candidates without the ability to sustain the fare by themselves. In short, ability to secure funding will not impact whether the application succeeds or not. Leerdoelen After completing this course students:
  • Are able to assess (at an elementary level) the scholarly debates in the field(s) of Law and Literature/Law and the Humanities.
  • Are able to assess the importance of the topics discussed for the (academic) study and (professional) practice of law.
  • Have gained insight into the relevance of knowledge of narrative and interpretation for law and legal practice.
  • Have gained a basic to develop their ability to reflect on their knowledge in writing.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud Economische activiteit zorgt aan de ene kant voor welvaart, werkgelegenheid en ontplooiingsmogelijkheden. Aan de andere kant is ze ook schadelijk voor de veiligheid en gezondheid van werknemers, consumenten en burgers en voor het milieu. De verdeling van verantwoordelijkheden in verband met de sturing van economische activiteit evolueert in de tijd en wordt op verschillende manieren benaderd. Door trends te verkennen en verschillende perspectieven te vergelijken kan veel worden geleerd over de manier waarop verschillende actoren economische activiteit sturen met het oog op de bescherming en bevordering van publieke doelen en hoe hierover wordt gedacht. Met betrekking tot de maatschappelijke impact van bedrijven en markten, en daarmee hun publieke rol, is een van de belangrijkste vragen welke regulerende en toezichthoudende instanties in staat zijn om hun activiteiten te sturen. Zoals de recente economische crisis en andere institutionele mislukkingen hebben aangetoond, blijft de sturing van bedrijven en markten niet beperkt tot command-and-control door overheidsinstellingen. Andere vormen van sturing, zoals zelfregulering, burgerparticipatie en consumentenboycots, worden ook ingezet om ervoor te zorgen dat ze hun maatschappelijke verantwoordelijkheid nemen. Als gevolg van de toenemende participatie van private actoren in de bescherming en bevordering van publieke doelen, verandert de traditionele rol van sturende overheden, terwijl de wisselwerking tussen publieke en private sturende instanties aan belang wint.
 
De cursus ‘Sturing in de hedendaagse samenleving’ behandelt de vraag hoe deze veranderende rollen en relaties tussen publieke en private actoren in de praktijk uitpakken. Deze vraag houdt verband met globalisering, bijvoorbeeld door de opkomst van grensoverschrijdende milieuproblemen, uitbuiting in mondiale productieketens en de toenemende rol van internationale instanties en INGOs en met individualisering, die zich bijvoorbeeld manifesteert in kritisch consumentengedrag. Gebruikmakend van moderne rechtssociologische en bestuurskundige theorieën, verkent deze cursus deze trends en de rol die verschillende actoren afzonderlijk en in onderlinge wisselwerking spelen in de sturing van economische activiteit. Leerdoelen Na het succesvol afronden van dit vak kunnen studenten: 
  1. begrijpen hoe de sturing van economische activiteit in een globaliserende economie plaatsvindt op verschillende niveaus (lokaal, nationaal en supranationaal), door verschillende actoren (overheden, marktpartijen, burgers en consumenten), ten aanzien van verschillende sociale vraagstukken (veiligheid, gezondheid, zorg en milieu);
  2. verschillende rechtssociologische en bestuurskundige perspectieven op toezicht en sturing identificeren en toepassen op concrete casussen;
  3. begrijpen met welke uitdagingen actoren en combinaties van actoren worden geconfronteerd bij de sturing van economische activiteit;
  4. kritisch reflecteren op sociaalwetenschappelijke theorieën over toezicht en sturing in de hedendaagse samenleving;
  5. actief deelnemen in werkgroepen en daarin opdrachten uit het blokboek met medestudenten bediscussiëren.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Leerdoelen

Het vak sturing van complexe vraagstukken gaat over de vraag wat vraagstukken anders maakt dan klassieke beleidsproblemen. Omdat vraagstukken anders zijn vragen ze ook om een andere sturing dan de sturing die wordt toegepast bij het oplossen van beleidsproblemen.  Na het doorlopen van de module kan de student:

  • Complexe vraagstukken in kaart brengen, theoretisch duiden en voorzien van sturingsvoorstellen die zich verhouden tot de complexiteit van het vraagstuk;
  • De manier waarop (semi-)publieke organisaties die zich vanuit een specifieke probleemdefinitie (constructivistische perspectief uit beleidsdynamiek)  bezig houden met vraagstukken construeren;
  • Veranderingen in de constructie van vraagstukken en eigen beleidsproblemen identificeren, conceptualiseren en analyseren;
  • Zichtbaar maken waar organisaties ‘vasthouden aan eigen probleemdefinities’ of juist meer nadruk leggen op het maatschappelijke vraagstuk als geheel;
  • De omgang met vraagstukken analyseren vanuit  Advocacy  Coalition  Framework, Punctuated Equilibrium Theory, multiple Streams Framework en Discourse Analysis);
  • De  complexe  relatie  tussen  beleidsproblemen  en  -oplossingen bij  het  verder  brengen  van  vraagstukken duiden in termen van aanbodsturing en vraagsturing;
  • Analyseren waar beleidsleren en –innovatie optreden rond vraagstukken en waar padafhankelijkheid en beperkte vermogens tot leren en innoveren optreden;
  • Strategieën  ontwikkelen  om  vraagstukken  centraal  te  stellen  en  beleidsleren  bij  complexe  vraagstukken centraal te stellen.

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)

text:
Inhoud

De volgende onderwerpen worden besproken:

  • Globaal het huwelijksvermogensrecht, het erfrecht en schenkingsrecht;
  • Woonplaatsbegrip en fictieve woonplaats;
  • Begrip kinderen, de gelijkstelling en het partnerbegrip;
  • Begrip vruchtgebruik en periodieke uitkering;
  • Fictiebepalingen;
  • Waardering van vermogensbestanddelen;
  • Bedrijfsopvolgingsregeling;
  • ANBI, SBBI, Steunstichting SBBI en Culturele Instelling;
  • Vrijstellingen en tarief
Leerdoelen
  • Inzicht verkrijgen in werking van de Successiewet en globaal van het huwelijksvermogensrecht, het erfrecht en schenkingsrecht.
  • Inzicht verkrijgen in de verschillen tussen de vermogensoverheveling bij leven en na overlijden.
  • Theoretisch en praktisch inzicht verkrijgen in de vermogensoverheveling tussen de generaties of naar derden, zoals goede doelen (ANBI’s). Tevens heeft de student inzicht in het eventuele effect van deze vermogensoverheveling voor de inkomstenbelasting en overdrachtsbelasting.
  • Inzicht verkrijgen in het eventuele effect van deze vermogensoverheveling voor de inkomstenbelasting en overdrachtsbelasting.

course_title: Summer Foundation Course in Corporate Communication
college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University

text:
Inhoud Instructors: prof. dr. P.J.F. Groenen (EUR), dr. P. Schoonees (EUR).

Short subject description:
Statistical learning methods arising from statistics, machine learning, and data science have become more widespread available. Machine learning methods can be split in supervised learning with the aim of predicting a response variable and unsupervised learning describing the relations between all variables simultaneously. This course focusses on supervised learning and has as its goal that the student obtains a thorough technical understanding of selection of supervised machine learning techniques, can choose between them sensibly, can implement the technique in a high level language such as R, python, Julia, or Octave, and can write a report about the technique.

Course content:
The book of Hastie, Tibshirani, and Friedman (2001, 1st edition) has been a milestone in connecting statistical ideas into machine learning techniques. Parts of this book will form the basis of this course. A tentative overview of techniques and ideas to be treated are a selection of linear methods for regression, linear methods for classification, basis expansion and regularization, model assessment and selection, classification and regression trees, ensemble learning (random forests, bagging, and bosting), regularized generalized canonical correlation analysis, partial least-squares, and support vector machines. Leerdoelen To understanding the fundamental building blocks of several machine learning methods, being able to choose from them, being able to program these methods, and being able to apply them sensibly.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud

Contents, course description
Supply chains are complex networks of organizations that supply and transform materials, and distribute final products and services to customers. Managing a supply change is a big challenge as well as an opportunity for both manufacturing and service industries. For a well designed and properly managed supply chain, firms must combine internal and external information in a dynamic fashion and focus on models, analytic tools to predict the future and gain a competitive advantage.

This course focuses on models and analytical tools to design and operate an effective supply chain. It adopts modern forecasting and machine learning methods to improve the performance of a supply chain while reducing the total cost. Students will have hands-on experience on real life applications of data analytics (descriptive, predictive, prescriptive) applied to several supply chain management topics such as

  • demand forecasting,
  • inventory management under uncertainty,
  • process analysis,
  • value of information and bullwhip effect in supply chains,
  • product design and delayed differentiation,
  • price optimization, revenue management.

R programming language will be widely used for solving the assignments.

Leerdoelen

Learning Objectives
This course explores models and effective analytics tools to design a successful supply chain. Demand forecasting and inventory management are two fundamental topics of supply chain analysis. In terms of demand forecasting, students will learn how to accurately predict the number of items to be sold next week/month/year based on a historical sales data. The mathematical and econometrics tools (i.e. time series analysis) will prove useful to forecast future demand. Once demand is estimated accurately, the next step is the inventory management. Here, several replenishment methods will be studied. In the remaining period, other relevant topics of supply chain management such as revenue management will also be discussed. At the end of the course students will:

  • Be able to examine and improve the supply chain operations such as flow of materials through a network of suppliers, manufacturers, distributors and retailers,
  • Be familiar with managing uncertainty in supply chains,
  • Understand tradeoffs to manage inventories in real world,
  • Familiarize themselves with analytical tools and models for effective solutions to problems in managing a supply chain,
  • Address the analytical challenges arising in supply chains.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
Success in a complex supply chain environment depends on your ability to make good decisions. This requires a systematic, data-driven and fact-based approach to decision-making and problem analysis. The same philosophy is also at the heart of scientific research. This course teaches you a variety of tools for business analytics and optimization modelling. You will explore the research that aims to solve decision problems in the supply chain management. Moreover, this course will prepare you for your thesis project, which starts in January.
 
Specific subjects include:
  • Business analysis in Excel
  • Linear and integer programming
  • Optimization software: CPLEX
  Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
Upon completion of this course students are prepared to:
  1. Use Excel for business analysis
  2. Solve business decision problems via optimization modelling
  3. Implement optimization models and approaches in CPLEX

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
The course is a mix of lectures, case studies, and games. The lectures are meant to explain supply chain models and concepts making use of both qualitative and quantitative methods. Qualitative methods involve theoretical frameworks, conceptual analysis, and evaluation of solution strategies whereas quantitative methods involve mathematical analysis, probability theory and basic concepts of microeconomics. Case studies depict a business scenario at a certain existing company; in which complex supply chain management decisions need to be taken. The situation is often partly described from the perspective of one of the key players in the decision–making process; furthermore, a certain degree of urgency is present as well. A teaching case requires very thorough preparation by the participant. Finally, students will be required to play game in a supply chain context, which will involve strategic and operational decisions.
To pass this core course, a participant needs to:
  • Participate actively in class;
  • Individual and group assignments (including game performance and reports) (40% of the final grade);
  • Take a written exam (60% of the final grade).
Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
Supply chain management has emerged as one of the major areas for companies to gain a competitive edge. Managing supply chains is a complex and challenging task, given the current business trends of expanding product variety, short product life cycles, increasing outsourcing, globalization of business, and continuous advances in information technology. This core course is intended for students with a strong interest in understanding logistics and operations – in either manufacturing or service industries – and the role supply chains and supply chain operations can play in business. The course will be particularly valuable for those who see their careers in operations/supply chain over the coming decade, or who see themselves consulting in operations/supply chain for client businesses. The course objectives are to:
  • Make you conversant in the language of supply chain management and expand your confidence in these area
  • Allow you to see the role of supply chain management in the overall strategy and performance of the firm by providing a conceptual, strategic view of supply chain design and operations
  • Analyze the underlying issues and trade-offs between the sourcing of raw materials, the manufacturing, storage, and transportation of products and the services required to fulfill customer expectations and the metrics of the firm
  • Provide you with quantitative and qualitative tools to identify, analyze and manage supply chain operations and issues
  • Analyze supply chains and supply chain operations to identify problems and improvement opportunities
  • Recommend and initiate supply chain improvement actions and projects
  • Enhance your team working and project management skills

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. M Becker-Peth', 'dr. S Lemmens', 'prof.dr. JYF Wynstra', 'prof.dr.ir. MBM de Koster']
text:
Inhoud Course Overview
Companies have over time specialized in a very limited number of business activities which they consider to be their core business. By doing so, they have been able to greatly increase their expertise, innovative capabilities and process efficiency. Companies have subsequently located their operations in regions that are most suitable in terms of natural resources, labor (either cheap or high grade), sales markets etc. As a consequence, a long chain of companies is involved in the manufacturing of products. These companies have limited insight into each other’s operations, and are often dispersed around the world. Such a situation requires that the chain of companies is effectively managed otherwise processes would falter, customers would have to be disappointed, and costs would surge. Therefore, supply chain management is vital to companies that operate in such chains. Proper planning and managing of the supply chain can make the difference between a successful business and an outright failure.

Progress in information technology has contributed to both the increasing need and opportunities for improved supply chain management. With IT, companies in a supply chain can be connected in real-time, which allows for efficient and effective sharing of information.

The course program presents cases of real-world situations calling for appropriate state-of-the-art models and solution methods for the design, planning, control and improvement of supply chain operations.

The course Supply Chain Management builds on the knowledge obtained in the course Operations Management offered in Bachelor 1.
  Leerdoelen In this course students are not only encouraged to acquire the necessary knowledge, but also to develop a critical attitude to the position of firms in relation to various strategic and operational choices related to the supply chain.

The course attempts to:
  • make you conversant in the language of supply chain management;
  • allow you to see the role of supply chain management in the overall strategy and performance of the firm by providing a conceptual, strategic view of supply chain design and operations;
  • enhance your critical thinking, not only in the area supply chain management but also as a future general manager;
  • provide you with qualitative and quantitative tools to identify, analyze, and manage basic supply chain management issues.

At the end of the course the student should be able to:
  • identify and use the main concepts and terminology in the domain of supply chain management;
  • select and use the appropriate instruments and tools to construct a supply chain management solution for a given situation;
  • identify and describe the needed design features of the supply chain;
  • recognize and use the different inventory replenishment strategies to control inventory levels;
  • clarify and leverage the value of information sharing as assisted by information technology for the integrated supply chain;
  • describe and choose the correct purchasing and sourcing strategy dependent on the features of a supply chain;
  • design the physical distribution in a supply chain and adopt the transportation accordingly;
  • identify the different (strategic) constructs for parties of the supply chain to collaborate, and to discuss and mitigate the accompanying risks;
  • analyse cases of real world situations and develop suitable supply chain management solutions.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. LP Veelenturf', 'dr. M Becker-Peth', 'prof.dr. JYF Wynstra', 'prof.dr.ir. MBM de Koster']

Course Information
Pre-requisites
Before taking this course it is strongly recommended that you have a firm grasp on the following concepts:
  • The fundamentals of Operations Management;
  • Quantitative Methods & Techniques: Statistics
  • Setting up a strategic business plan;
  • Some knowledge of Marketing, Information and Organizational management.

course_title: Supply Chain Management: Industriële economie en bedrijfshuishoudkunde
text:
Inhoud

Demand & Supply Chain Management omvat het management van de keten die onafhankelijke klanten en leveranciers verbindt als ware het een enkele entiteit met het doel om waarde te creëren en verspillingen te verminderen door de vrijwillige planning en coördinatie van de doelen en activiteiten van alle betrokken actoren.
Drie analyseniveau's:

  • In één vestiging
  • Meerdere vestigingen van één onderneming
  • Tussen ondernemingen

Theoriebasis:

  • Transactiekosteneconomie
  • Speltheorie
  • Resource based view

Capita selecta:

  • Opslingereffecten
  • Netwerk- en platformeconomie
  • Veerkrachtige ketens
  • Ontwerpregels DSCM
Leerdoelen
  • Genereren en selecteren van mogelijke Demand & Supply Chain Management alternatieven.
  • Implementatievereisten van Demand & Supply Chain Management alternatieven onderkennen.
  • Gebruik maken van economische theorievorming om win-winsituaties in Demand & Supply Chain Management te onderkennen, te ontwerpen en te implementeren.
  • De inventarisatie en analyse van Demand & Supply Chain Management vraagstukken te kunnen maken (vanuit het oogpunt van een beleidsbeslisser).
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Enkele voorbeelden uit de colleges zijn n.a.v. de actualiteit aangepast.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
Modern supply chain management involves decision making in uncertain, dynamic, and complex environments. This course focusses on the use of simulation techniques to make better supply chain decisions under such conditions. For that purpose, the course combines relevant theoretical knowledge with immediate application of simulation techniques on computer-based tools. In particular, we use Monte Carlo simulations, discrete event simulations, and system dynamics approaches. In all cases, real-life supply chains are represented in computer models. These models serve as a safe playground to study and evaluate supply chain decision making. We gain essential knowledge to improve supply chain performance.
​
The theoretical foundations for the course are provided in the weekly lectures. Most of the learning, however, happens while you work hands-on on the weekly (individual) assignments, and on the longer group assignment that spans the whole duration of the course. During the weekly workshops, you can get support from teaching staff while getting started on the individual assignment. During the lab session later in the week, you have the chance to ask questions arising while continuing the assignments at home. Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
In this course, you learn how to build, interpret, and use simulation models to analyze processes and to support decision making.
  • After completing this course, you will be able to
  • Understand and apply the key concepts of Monte Carlo simulations, discrete event simulations, as well as system dynamics;
  • Build and verify simulation models in Arena and Excel
  • Analyze and prepare input data for use in a simulation model
  • Validate a simulation model
  • Run experiments with a simulation model, and draw conclusions on the process modelled
  • Understand the concept of decision making under uncertainty
  • Gain insight into how the quality of a solution is affected by unknown factors and by an unknown future

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
The forecasting of product demand, new product success, risk events, prices, costs and capacity dynamics is an important activity in every day decision making in companies throughout the supply chain. It directly affects inventory management, procurement and production decisions, logistics resources and financial planning, and thus has a strong impact on the performance of individual companies, as well as that of a supply chain as a whole. The Supply Chain Forecasting elective is about acquiring a robust understanding of common and advanced forecasting methods used in practice, and about training programming skills to apply these methods in practical situations.  

In particular, the following topics will be covered: 

  • Forecasting methods based on smoothing 
  • Econometric models, e.g., arima(x) 
  • Machine learning techniques, e.g., decision trees, random forests, gradient boosting; and ensemble forecasting 
  • Assessing the performance of forecasts 
  • Forecasting intermittent demand, and the relation between forecasting and inventory management 
  • Judgmental forecasting, and the influence of judgmental adjustments on forecast performance
Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
The learning objectives of this course are: 
  • Understand and apply the common forecasting and analytics methods used in business, both in terms of assumptions and operation  
  • Ability to apply forecasting and analytics in programming, involving data processing, selection and application of relevant analytical functions, collect and present the outcomes of analyses; solve non-trivial statistical problems using a programming language and environment, e.g., R and RStudio 
  • Design and perform a scientific study aimed at answering a practical, forecasting-oriented question, report outcomes in solid writing and convincing presentation 
  • Demonstrate the ability to effectively communicate ideas, solution approaches, and findings to diverse stakeholders.   
  • Critically reflect on ethical ramifications of data collection, team work and proposed implementations of analytical findings.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. S Lemmens', 'prof.dr. JYF Wynstra', 'prof.dr.ir. MBM de Koster']
text:
Inhoud Bedrijven zijn zich in toenemende mate gaan specialiseren op een beperkt aantal kernactiviteiten (de zogenaamde ‘core business’). Door deze specialisatie zijn bedrijven in staat om op hun deelgebied veel kennis op te bouwen, innovatieve producten te ontwikkelen en efficiënt te werken. Bedrijven vestigen zich op locaties die voor hun specialisme het meest geschikt zijn. Dit kan zijn vanwege de beschikbaarheid van grondstoffen, goedkope of juist hoogwaardige arbeidskrachten, belangrijke afzetmarkten, etc. Als gevolg van deze specialisatie is een lange keten van bedrijven betrokken bij de fabricage van een eindproduct. Bedrijven die vaak een beperkt inzicht hebben in elkaars activiteiten en die verspreid over de hele wereld kunnen zitten. Een dergelijke situatie vereist dat de keten van bedrijven goed gemanaged wordt omdat anders de processen vastlopen, klanten teleurgesteld moeten worden en kosten hoog oplopen. Supply chain management is daarom van cruciaal belang voor bedrijven die zich in dergelijke ketens bevinden. Het plannen en managen van de supply chain kan het verschil maken tussen een succesvol bedrijf en een complete mislukking.

De vooruitgang in informatietechnologie heeft bijgedragen aan zowel de stijgende behoefte als aan de toenemende kansen voor een verbeterd supply chain management. Met behulp van IT kunnen bedrijven hun supply chain koppelen aan real-time informatie en kan op een effectieve en efficiënte manier kennis gedeeld worden.

In dit vak worden verscheidene bedrijfscases gepresenteerd die vragen om state-of-the-art modellen en oplossingsmethoden voor ontwerp, planning, beheersing en verbetering van supply chains.

Het vak Supply Chain Management bouwt voort op de kennis die verkregen is in het vak Primaire Processen (Bachelor 1). Leerdoelen Dit vak moedigt studenten aan niet alleen de vereiste kennis te vergaren, maar ook om een kritische houding te verwerven ten aanzien van de positie van bedrijven in relatie tot de verschillende strategische en operationele keuzes gerelateerd aan de supply chain.

Het vak streeft er naar om:
  • de student de taal van supply chain management te laten begrijpen en gebruiken;
  • de student inzicht te geven in de rol die supply chain management speelt in de bedrijfsstrategie en de prestaties van de organisatie;
  • de student kritisch te laten kijken en denken over zowel supply chain management als andere aspecten van het managen van een organisatie;
  • de student te voorzien van kwalitatieve en kwantitatieve tools om hem in staat te stellen eenvoudige supply chain management vraagstukken te identificeren, analyseren en op te lossen.

Aan het eind van het vak moeten de studenten in staat zijn om:
  • de belangrijkste concepten en terminologie uit het supply chain management vakgebied te benoemen en te gebruiken;
  • de juiste instrumenten en methoden te kiezen en te gebruiken om een supply chain management oplossing te genereren voor een bepaald probleem;
  • de ontwerpkenmerken van de supply chain te benoemen en uit te leggen;
  • de verschillende voorspellingsmethoden in supply chain management toe te passen
  • de verschillende voorraadbestelstrategieën te herkennen en te gebruiken om voorraadniveaus te beheersen;
  • de waarde van informatiedeling duidelijk te maken en te gebruiken, ondersteund door informatie technologie voor de geïntegreerde supply chain;
  • de juiste inkoop- en sourcingstrategieën te beschrijven en te kiezen afhankelijk van de kenmerken van een supply chain;
  • de fysieke distributie in een supply chain in te richten en het transport hierop aan te passen;
  • de verschillende (strategische) samenwerkingsvormen te benoemen tussen partijen in een supply chain en de bijbehorende risico’s te identificeren en te reduceren;
  • echte bedrijfscases te analyseren en hiervoor gepaste supply chain oplossingen te ontwikkelen.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. M Becker-Peth', 'dr. S Lemmens', 'prof.dr. JYF Wynstra', 'prof.dr.ir. MBM de Koster']
text:
