college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud Surveillance denotes the collection of personal information for purposes of control. It is a primary organising logic among states and organisations, but also activists and other individuals. Surveillance involves the use of emerging technologies, as well as longstanding forms of management and governance, in order to make the social world knowable and assert a particular social order.

This course aims to situate surveillance practices in diverse institutions, in order to recognise their social, cultural and communicative purpose in contemporary societies. This course treats surveillance as a topic that garners public concern, with the goal of contributing to theoretical and empirical accounts to these understandings.

Students will consider surveillance practices across institutional and cultural contexts. This will involve applying concepts and assumptions to a range of developments. Each week addresses a particular context in which surveillance occurs, and bridges digitally mediated with embodied practices. Students will participate in and occasionally lead discussions on particular forms of surveillance, and their social, cultural, informational and ethical dimensions and implications. Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding of
- Foundational conceptual frameworks and theoretical perspectives about surveillance practices across social contexts
- Historically and culturally situated accounts of information technologies

Students have developed the skills to
- Apply concepts and empirical insights about surveillance practices to relevant contexts, notably linking emerging cases with historic precedents
- Appraise public discourses in order to interpret how surveillance practices are shaped and normalised
- Critically engage with surveillance studies scholarship to consider its relevance to digital media and communication studies

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud

New technologies and related practices are a source of excitement, anxiety and inspiration. This is especially the case when these technologies are used to monitor people, or allow those people to monitor others. Shared understandings of emerging and controversial technologies are shaped by popular media representations in entertainment. Science-fiction, sitcoms and song lyrics (among other sources) provide coherent and lasting accounts of what it feels like to watch or be watched. Moreover, the way we watch others through media such as reality television and live-streaming also shapes our understanding of what kinds of surveillance are acceptable.

This course explores the role of the media in accounting for surveillance practices and digitalisation. This includes a historic and multi-cultural overview of the viewer society. Upon discussing and engaging with relevant concepts and methodological approaches, students will carry out small scale empirical analysis of media content.

Leerdoelen

Students have knowledge and understanding of:

  • Theoretical frameworks and concepts that enable understandings of representations of surveillance practices.
  • Appropriate methods of (visual) document analysis.

Students have developed the skills to:

  • Analyse and interpret media documents in terms of qualitative and culturally situated analytic frameworks.
  • Report on their preliminary and conclusive findings in oral and written form.
  • Critically reflect on methodological limitations and possible societal implications of their research.

course_title: Surveillance in Film, TV, and Media Platforms
college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud The course’s primary focus is the representation of surveillance and intelligence on screen (TV/streaming services, film, and, to some extent, documentary). A working concept will be that surveillance and intelligence are related concepts and that it is worth exploring the historical dimensions of these concepts. The theoretical literature is mainly concerned with the social, philosophical, and media perspectives on surveillance and intelligence. In the seminar we will see how developments in surveillance techniques give rise to questions about the price of information gathering. We shall treat SF movies, TV series and documentaries as reflecting contemporary concerns with surveillance and intelligence. Black Mirror episodes are an obvious reference point, but think also of a film like Das Leben der Anderen. Leerdoelen
·         Students will have gained insight into course relevant theoretical debates on surveillance and intelligence
·         Students can compare and contrast the representation of surveillance and intelligence in film, documentary, and TV in an international perspective
·         Students can relate the relevant theoretical issues to such representations

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud The continued growth of social media platforms, mobile devices and related cultural practices has contributed to a dramatic increase in the quantity of information that any individual or organisation can access. Citizens can use this information in an emerging cultural practice known as ‘digital vigilantism’ where they identify offensive behaviour and bring the offender to a kind of ‘online justice’ by making them visible through naming and shaming practices. These practices are manifest in digital and conventional media in multiple ways. For example:
 
  • Citizens can make use of social media platforms (such as Facebook, Twitter and Tumblr) as well as social news sites (such as Reddit or Geenstijl) to shame other individuals, as well as share personal details about the target (‘doxing’).
  • Citizens may also turn to online review platforms such as Amazon and Tripadvisor (or make use of review functions in Facebook or Google) to denounce and shame targets (for example, by leaving one-star reviews).
  • News media (including broadsheets, tabloids, and online venues such as Huffington Post and BuzzFeed) may also provide coverage of these campaigns, augmenting the visibility of the incident.
 
These developments demand conceptual and empirical attention from emerging media scholars. Students will develop research questions for a small-scale empirical project addressing (aspects of) one of these focal points. They will make use of qualitative content analyses on a range of media data, including news reports, editorials, and other public data sources.
  Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding of:
  • State-of the art theory on the topic of surveillance, vigilantism and mediated shaming.
  • Common research designs and methods to examine online denunciations.
Students have developed the skills to:
  • Design and execute a small scale empirical study on the topic of digital vigilantism.
  • Report on their preliminary and conclusive research findings in oral and written form.
  • Critically reflect on the limitations and the possible societal implications of their research, with an emphasis on challenges and opportunities associated with research on and through digital media platforms.

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
lecturers: ['A.P. Heikema', 'dr. F.L. van Vliet', 'dr. R.A. Gruters', 'prof. dr. R.A.M. Fouchier']

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
In many countries and industries, sustainability accounting is now acknowledged as an essential process of business operation where companies develop measures for their environmental, social, and governance performances; ensure their reliability; report to stakeholders; and assist managers in making critical decisions for their companies and society. However, adopting and implementing such a complex managerial system has become more and more challenging as the demand from stakeholders for responsible business has grown substantially during the past decades as well. This course offers a comprehensive overview of managerial processes involved in sustainability accountability. Students will learn basic concepts, theories and practices and be given opportunities to apply their knowledge and critical thinking to evaluating sustainability reports and standards. Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
The goal of this course is to broaden students’ understanding of sustainability accountability. At the end of the course, students will be able to:
  1. Recognize the distinguishable processes through which sustainability is measured, assured, and reported.
  2. Examine various types of sustainability measurement/reporting standards
  3. Evaluate the quality of sustainability reports
  4. Explain the typical challenges faced by companies regarding sustainability accounting

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud Communicating sustainability effectively is of critical importance in a world where multiple socio-environmental concerns impact and disrupt everyday life. Aligning with the UN Sustainable Development Goals, this course explores some key sustainability narratives and communication challenges. We will study the role of the media and other critical actors while examining actionable messaging techniques and communication strategies. Participants will undertake hands-on approaches to both identify sustainability communication challenges and develop related communication solutions and strategies. Leerdoelen After this course, students will be able to:
  • Understand complex, environment-specific media discourses and their influence on public perception
  • Evaluate and critically reflect on gaps in sustainability communication and barriers to effective environmental messaging
  • Apply theoretical insights and developments in communication best practices to evaluate contemporary examples and cases
  • Create actionable communication strategies to support issue-specific sustainability transformations

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
This course focuses on the sustainability grand challenges of our times. Sustainability grand challenges can refer to environmental or ecological problems as well as social problems. Examples include climate change, land degradation and natural disasters or global displacement, poverty and inequality. Grand challenges are global problems that require combined efforts and new innovative approaches to better understand, harness, and tackle them. 

In this course, you will collaborate to analyze a sustainability grand challenge and formulate ‘solutions’ by engaging multiple partners and by thinking out-of-the-box. Specifically, you work together to create a novel and (commercially) viable solution to a real-world grand challenge. The main learning goal of this course is to understand and harness a grand challenge. 

You will work individually as well as in teams and under significant time pressures to analyze the grand challenge and jointly formulate a credible and feasible ‘solution’. You will individually demonstrate your understanding of the grand challenge with an individual essay and by reviewing one of your peers, and jointly develop and assess a solution in a group report. You will present the solution in the group report to a multi-stakeholder jury at the end of the course. Your groups will need to apply your learning of structuring and delivery of a message in time-restricted and context-sensitive ‘pitching’ format for this presentation. 

Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
After completing this course, students are able to:
  • Evaluate the sustainability grand challenge using different theoretical frameworks on wicked problems, temporality and scale;
  • Jointly analyze the stakeholders related to the sustainability grand challenge;
  • Jointly develop a solution to harness the sustainability grand challenge;
  • Jointly reflect on the viability of the developed solution;
  • Jointly deliver a convincing pitch suitable for the boardroom.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud

Contents, course description
Our world is facing severe global social and environmental challenges. Human population is growing, while the resource base it relies on for wellbeing continues to decline. We have surpassed the ecological thresholds of some of the planetary boundaries that govern a safe space for humanity, while others are being encroached with short windows of opportunity for solutions. Basic needs of many of the world’s people remain unmet, while inequality has grown to the extent that the world’s richest 62 people are worth more than the poorest 50% of the world’s global population.

Sustainability has now long been a boardroom agenda, yet our ecological systems continue to degrade and many social issues remain unresolved. The reality check for business leadership is that nine billion people simply cannot live well in this world if companies do not start finding new solutions to co-create a safe operating space for humanity. In this course we consider how business leaders are taking this challenge seriously.

The goal of this course is to broaden participants’ understanding of sustainability, allowing for a holistic recognition of the interconnectivity of issues and their impacts on the future of business. Participants will learn the basics concepts of corporate sustainability and the meaning of ‘true corporate sustainability’ from a holistic and embedded perspective. The course engages with how and why companies form sustainability strategies and considers how an embedded perspective can be achieved through tools such as the planetary boundaries framework. Participants will be immersed in how strategies may be implemented through a range of the contemporary advancements in sustainability leadership such as sustainable business models, integrated reporting and the circular economy.

Students should attend and actively participate in the classes. Students are expected to engage in class discussions, ask questions of speakers, and demonstrate involvement with group exercises.

Leerdoelen

Learning Objectives
After following this course, the student is able to:

  • Explain business sustainability from a holistic and embedded perspective.
  • Analyse how and why sustainability challenges occur within social-ecological systems.
  • Explain how firms can use systems and resilience thinking to effectively change how social-ecological systems behave.
  • Apply systems thinking to create business models for sustainability.
  • Evaluate organizational responses to sustainability challenges from a systems perspective.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. MJJ Wubben', 'L Versteegt, MSc', 'LDM De Schutter, MSc', 'prof.dr. SP Kaptein']
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
With the global population growing to 9.7 billion people, the World Business Council for Sustainable Development forecasts that if organizations do not drastically revise their way of doing business, humanity will be consuming the ecological resources of 2.3 earths in 2050. To avert the disaster that would ensue, organizations need to foster sustainable development by helping to meet the needs of the present generation without compromising the needs of future generations. This requires a focus not only on economic, but also on environmental and social performance.  

Such a focus is not self-evident. Think of high-profile scandals such as the Enron, Worldcom, and Parmalat debacles, not to mention the global banking crisis. The economic, social, and environmental consequences of such drastic, moral transgressions may be so profound that they potentially nullify any sustainable development. Yet even for the many organizational members—CEOs and employees alike—that do embrace sustainability, dilemmas and challenges arise: When should environmental outcomes prevail over social outcomes? How much should we rely on technological solutions? How can we and our stakeholders bridge the gap between good intentions and good behavior? These issues show that sustainability and ethics go hand in hand, and that both present and future business leaders need to embody both.

This course offers a broad, psychological and philosophical perspective on sustainable, moral behaviour in business. How can such behaviour be encouraged in employees, in CEOs, in organizations as a whole, and in their stakeholders? Conversely, how can unsustainable, immoral behaviour be averted? Such questions will be discussed in the context of, among others, normative stakeholder theory, greenwashing, green consumerism, social dilemmas, environmental ethics, and moral development and sustainable values in individuals and organizations.

This course emphasizes linking theory, research and practice, and therefore so do the course assignments. As a first assignment, you and your research team will therefore either (a) carry out a quantitative, applied research project on a topic relevant to sustainability and ethics, or (b) conduct research using CSR-reporting from companies either to identify and provide solutions for moral challenges that these companies are facing or to evaluate the fairness of the criteria used by an NGO that ranks brands on sustainability (depending on whether collaboration with this NGO remains possible). Both assignments will allow you to further apply theory and literature on sustainability and ethics, as well as to subject your own ideas to (empirical) scrutiny, and to communicate your findings concisely, accurately, clearly and straightforwardly in a paper of 2500 words maximum. You and your team will also present your research to your fellow students, allowing you to further practice communicating your ideas.

The second assignment consists of an individual 1000-word essay where you will reflect on material from at least two different lectures. This gives you the opportunity to creatively process the course material. Perhaps you see previously unimagined potential in some of the theories discussed in the lectures, allowing you to propose brand new applications for sustainable development in business. Perhaps you see ways to improve existing theories and make them more relevant to practice. Or perhaps you are skeptical of certain theories, the link between theory and practice, or the value of the empirical research discussed in the lectures.

This course consists of six lectures, two consultation sessions, and one presentation session. Active participation during the lectures may count toward one’s final grade. Leerdoelen
Learning Objectives
  • To understand the ways in which sustainability and morality are intertwined.
  • To understand what drives sustainable, moral behaviour in employees, in CEOs, and in organizations as a whole.
  • To become more self-aware of one’s moral development and sustainable values.
  • To translate empirical research and theory on sustainability and business ethics into real-world interventions.

course_title: Sustainability in the Visual Arts and Crafts
college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud This course provides an introduction to and application of key concepts and developments in thinking about sustainability in contemporary societies and cities, covering environmental, social and economic dimensions. From the early conceptualizations of sustainable development to the UN Sustainable Development Goals, from the Anthropocene to the climate crisis, from the doughnut and circular economy to green growth and greenwashing – we will start by reviewing and critically assessing the contribution of different concepts to contemporary societal challenges. Then we will apply these concepts to an exploration of sustainable practices in the fields of contemporary visual arts and crafts, mapping out key developments in production, consumption and communication. We will critically assess the potential of small-scale urban making and crafts to offer solutions for sustainable forms of production and consumption practices, exploring opportunities and potential pitfalls. Moreover, we will appraise the role that the visual arts can play in addressing sustainability topics, and we will explore what (un)sustainable practices can occur in the (visual) arts world. By the end of this course, students will have the ability to reproduce and critically discuss some of the most influential concepts and approaches to sustainable development in contemporary visual arts and crafts Leerdoelen

This course offers an introduction to notions and debates around sustainability in contemporary societies and applies these notions to an exploration of sustainable practices in crafts and the visual arts. By the end of this course, students will have the ability to:

  • Recognize and explain central concepts and debates in contemporary theoretical and policy approaches to sustainability
  • Analyse key sustainability trends in the production, consumption and communication practices, notably in the fields of the visual arts and crafts
  • Critically assess sustainability concepts and apply them to case studies in the fields of contemporary visual arts and crafts.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
This course provides insight in the sustainability challenges and the link to finance. The main task of the financial system is to allocate funding to its most productive use. Traditional finance focuses on financial return and regards the financial sector as separate from the society of which it is part and the environment in which it is embedded. By contrast, sustainable finance considers financial, social, and environmental returns in combination and shows how finance can accelerate the transition to a low-carbon, inclusive economy.

The course reviews evidence that environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors matter and explains in detail how to incorporate these in company business models and strategies, equity investing, bond investing, and bank lending. The course examines the financial instruments and techniques that can be applied in the context of evolving climate policies (and other sustainability policies). The tools will be applied in a group assignment on the valuation of a company based on ESG factors. Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
Students will learn to critically review the externalities embedded in sustainability challenges, to link climate change science with the evolution of financial markets, and to identify the sustainability risks and opportunities for financial professionals. In terms of applications, students will gain knowledge of the main metrics and financial instruments related to sustainability, and of the techniques to measure and manage the exposure of investment and lending portfolios.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
Corporate sustainability, inclusive business, corporate (social) responsibility, and shared value creation have been widely embraced by a wide variety of firms. These buzz words basically refer to a firm’s pursuit of social and ecological objectives in addition to the classic economic goals. But what does a strategy to achieve corporate sustainability really look like?
Building on Hambrick and Fredrickson’s (Academy of Management Executive, 2005) well-known article “Are you sure you have a strategy?,” five components of a sustainable strategy will be identified: a sustainability logic (why to go for sustainable business?), sustainability differentiators (how to make a sustainability-related difference?), sustainability vehicles (how to engage a variety of stakeholders?), arenas of sustainable business (in what sustainability markets?), and staging of a sustainable strategy (how to unfold a sustainable strategy over time?).
 
You will first discover state-of-the-art literature at the interface of corporate strategy and corporate sustainability. Each of the five academic sessions will cover one core strategy component. You will study several relevant articles and make an individual assignment prior to the session. During the classes we will discuss strengths and limitations of the readings, relate each component to other strategy elements, and apply the topic to actual business practices.
 
Next to the classroom setting, you will conduct fieldwork in a group of students. You will observe a concrete firm that has recently implemented a sustainable strategy. In particular, you will identify a concrete (successful or failed) project—the environmental certification of a particular product, the internationalization of a ‘sustainable product’, development of inclusive business, etc.—and analyze this project using conceptual insights from the academic literature. Drawing on interviews and secondary data, you will comprehensively grasp the essence and details of the project, critically analyze the strengths and limitations of the adopted strategy, and offer constructive suggestions to the focal company to improve their practices. Every group will present the analysis and suggestions during the sixth and final session of the course.
  Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
  • To gain an in-depth theoretical understanding of the components and interrelations of economically, environmentally, and socially sustainable strategies
  • To critically evaluate and compare different theories on sustainable strategies
  • To chart the ‘real-life’ practices of sustainable business opportunities and threats
  • To apply theoretical insights to the actual setting of a firm pursuing a sustainable strategy
  • To develop the skills to analyze all factors and actors relevant to an actual sustainable business project

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
The Sustainable and Equitable Food Stategies (SEFS) course aims at applying a transdisciplinary approach to answer wicked problems in global food sector, with a blend of life sciences such as biology, chemistry, technology, and social sciences, such as communication, economy and management. The ultimate goal is to help students in discovering the origin, the taste and the nutritional value of our food supply, as well as understanding the interactions between the actors of "global food chain" (such as governments, international institutions, local market/producers, the big food corporations and supermarket chains) that shape our diets.  Sustainability of the food production and consumption will be analyzed from United Nation’s Sustainability Goals, taking both environmental and social aspects into consideration.

The course draws on using a problem-oriented project-work approach by implementing action learning techniques, as well as social media engagement through personal food journals and business case assessments, with a particular focus on corporate social responsibility and responsible citizenship. Major themes include the nutritional, sustainable and equitable properties of food, transformations in food industry and global regulations, and the interactions between food processing, diets and health. Particular attention will be dedicated to DIY sustainability of food that will be tackled from different perspectives, such as healthy dietary patterns, environmental impact of food production (e.g. organic vs industrial food; processed/non processed food; animal based vs plant-based food) and societal drawbacks (food security and the fight against malnutrition). In order to realize this ambition, the course will collaborate with Erasmus Food Lab for cooking workshops and with Campus Garden for gardening workshops where all theoretical knowledge will be put into practice, together with students and sustainable food and agriculture practitioners. 
  Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
After completing the course, the students will be able to:

Knowledge
  1. Acquire an in-depth and systematic knowledge on the management of sustainable and equitable food strategies.
    1. Identify the main components of food, and recall both their health benefits and negative consequences;
    2. Analyze the global and local aspects of food production and consumption from a transformative approach;
    3. Develop strategies in order to create a positive impact for a healthy, sustainable and equitable food system;
Skills
  1. Students are able to design and promote sustainable and equitable food projects.
    1. Apply a self-inquiry in the form of a daily food journal and evaluate individual and organizational actions and behavior against a framework for sustainable and responsible food practices in interaction with food businesses and organizations;
    2. Engage others in order to promote sustainable and equitable food strategies using different social media channels

Attitudes
  1. Develop action-based attitudes to lead transformative changes in organizations
    1. Originate a reflexive and creative attitude to transfer self-gathered knowledge and skills to others
    2. Create professional collaboration and develop communication skills to promote sustainability within organizations and towards society

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud
Contents, course description
Corporate leaders from smaller as well as larger companies, as start-ups as well as big corporates, are nowadays searching for new and more innovative value propositions that can be linked to more future looking and crisis resilient business models. Partly the search is for rejuvenating existing business models, but increasingly the business models introduced are a response to a society that is considered non-sustainable. Enter: the search for sustainable business models. In the literature this tendency is also referred to as ‘shared value creation’, ‘social innovation’ or ‘business model innovation’. Many synonyms are introduced for this ambition. Most of them look at societal issues from a business model (micro level: how to organise it) as well as from a societal level (macro level: what positive consequences will we have from the wide-spread introduction of the business model).  
Leerdoelen
Learning Objectives
  • Business models: Understanding how company’s ‘value propositions’ are created and implemented in the Netherlands and around the world; we will use various versions and elaborations of the business model CANVAS as red threat for the whole course and for structured conversations.
  • Wicked problems: Looking at new business models and the way they can create value and/or solve ‘ wicked’  societal problems in general and the sustainable development goals in specific
  • Context: Considering the extent to which business models can become sustainable in varying contexts: international (the influence of country and regulation), per sector, per issue that companies are confronted with
  • Critical: Understanding the pros and cons of a variety of new economic models, that are related to new business models: circular economy, the we/shared-economy, the upcoming relevance of (energy) cooperatives; social enterprises
  • Understanding what the start-up conditions for new and innovative business models are: such as for instance ‘ social enterprise’ and their challenge to get out of the ‘valley of death’
  • Incumbents and innovation: Understanding what business model innovation looks like from the perspective of ‘incumbents’  (firms that have already a leading position in a market)
  • New institutional and organizational forms: studying partnerships as part of sustainable business model innovation around the world; from the perspective of companies, NGOs and governments
  • Sharing: understanding what the business case for ‘shared value creation’ could look like for firms and value chains; how the micro-level of a firm (input dimension of sustainability) can be linked to the macro-level of society (output/outcome dimension of sustainability); how ‘good intentions’  can lead to ‘ bad outcomes’.
  • Leadership and motivation: what distinguishes a sustainable leader from a non-sustainable leader? If so desired: defining your own leadership potential and checking how leadership is needed for business model innovation (use the leadership profiler)
  • Support in your Master thesis effort (provided you write a master thesis that is linked to the sustainable business models theme); this elective will directly support your master thesis ambitions by linking theory to practice (and hopefully also practical applications)

Inhoud Music moves us physically and emotionally. Even when we don't move, brain areas related to movement are active when we hear music. Yet traditionally, music has by and large been studied from written scores, which can tell us many things. Scores do not, however, tell us how that music actually sounds or makes us feel. Moreover, it lacks the second most important aspect of music: movement. In recent years, developing technologies and blurring borders between scientific fields have paved the way for studying music from the perspective of human movement. Embodied Music Cognition is an exciting young field in musicology, which has as its core premise that movement in all its facets provides a unique window into musical and human behaviour. This course introduces students to many facets of the field, including the origins and purpose(s) of music, neuroscience, digital audio and emotions, and offers 4 weeks of intensive hands-on experience with students running, analysing and writing up their own music research project.


Leerdoelen After completing the course students will be able to discuss the link between music (perception) and human movement, especially in terms of evolutionary auditory specialization, in terms of interpersonal coordination and in terms of the effects of musical training on the brain. Students will be able to argue that without movement, there is no music, neither played nor perceived. Students will have had an introduction to several behavioral measurement techniques, digital audio analysis, experiment design, as well as scientific reporting. Finally, students will be able to bridge gaps between research fields in the sense of applying existing research methods and questions to a field that these methods were not developed for.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
Ask any business leader to mention the most important drivers for his/her success and you’ll find that “my ability to hire the best people in my teams” is one of them. With the above in mind these 4 observations are striking: (a) in business schools, there is zero to none academic training in “hiring people”, (b) almost no companies train their managers profoundly on this skill, (c) Tasks around “hiring people”, like job interviews, make up for a large part of a business leader’s day to day agenda, especially in more senior career stages, and (d) the academic state-of-the art knowledge on what is good practice has multiple extreme gaps with what happens in everyday business life. For instance, many organizations still base selection decisions on invalid and unreliable selection methods, thus making a bad-informed hiring decision. 

In this course we will take two perspectives to which related learning goals are related. First, you as a hiring manager: boosting your ability to make effective hiring decisions yourself. Second, you as a business leader: enhancing your ability to contribute strategically to the talent-acquisition goals of others in an organization. 

In order to achieve these goals, this course will provide insights in the fundamentals of the talent acquisition process, how to effectively acquire/match talent to business needs and modern-day talent acquisition/recruitment/selection methods. The course engages students through a combination of lectures, practical case studies, debates, exercises and discussions.     Leerdoelen Learning Objectives

1.    Understand the fundamentals of talent acquisition, recruitment and selection methods;
2.    Explain the interfaces between talent acquisition and other elements of the organization;
3.    Apply the theoretical knowledge to a business case;
4.    Be able to critically evaluate business cases.

Inhoud

To be determined.

Leerdoelen
  • The aim of this course is to foster the ability of students to conduct economic research on a policy relevant topic.
  • Students can write a well structured research proposal.
  • Students can answer a policy relevant question with methods used by applied economists.
  • Students can write a short well structured research paper.
  • Students can present their work to policymakers and fellow students.
  • Students train their ability to conduct an applied policy analysis themselves.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Omwille van de coronamaatregelen zullen er dit jaar minder fysieke begeleidingsmomenten zijn, en wordt het bezoek aan het ministerie van financiën waarschijnlijk geannuleerd. We beperken ons dit jaar tot econometrische opdrachten.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
Taxes affect many business decisions, such as: where to invest, what organizational form to choose, how to finance a business, when and where to recognize revenues and expenses. This is an introductory course providing you with an overview of what taxes exist, to which natural or legal persons they apply, how taxation affects business decisions, and what the fundamentals of domestic and international taxation are.
 
The course combines financial accounting, tax accounting, and investment principles to answer the question: How do I take tax-optimal business decisions? This knowledge is complemented by information about recent political developments in the area of taxation. The content from the lecture is applied and deepened during workshops. Guest lectures provide additional insights from practice.
 
The fundamentals in domestic and international taxation form basic knowledge of auditors, tax advisors, and practitioners in the accounting or tax departments of multinationals. Thus, the course is of interest to those contemplating careers in accounting, consulting, and corporate finance. Leerdoelen
Learning Objectives
On completion of this course, students should be able to:
  1. Define different taxes levied by governments;
  2. Solve tasks that include taxes in financial planning;
  3. Analyze the impact of taxation on organizational form choices;
  4. Evaluate when business profits and when shareholder level profits are taxed; 
  5. Evaluate double tax agreements and multilateral agreements in the area of international taxation;
  6. Evaluate measures to curb tax avoidance;
  7. Create recommendations for business decisions including taxes and present them in a report.

Inhoud

In international taxation, the most prominent and hotly debated issue is how to tax multinational companies. In other words, the debate is about how to handle profit-shifting activities by multinationals, or international corporate tax avoidance in more general. Anecdotic evidence shows that large multinational companies such as Google and Apple, but also IKEA manage to avoid almost all tax payments. Even state-owned companies like the Norwegian Equinor (formerly Statoil) use international tax shelters to reduce their global tax payments.

The issue became a major challenge to public policy. Being concerned about losses in tax revenue and an imbalance in the distribution of the tax burden on individuals and firms, the G20 countries and the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) started the still ongoing “Base Erosion and Profit Shifting” (BEPS) project in 2012 that in recent years came up with various proposals to regulate firms’ activities and their scope to shift profits. In its 2013-report, the OECD states that “at stake is the integrity of the corporate income tax”.

On the other hand, corporate income taxes are (one of) the biggest cost blocks in corporations, and it appears natural that firms try to reduce costs and respond to tax incentives. Indeed, (some) profit shifting can reduce the distortions created by taxing mobile capital investment and help to implement a beneficial tax differentiation between mobile and immobile tax bases.

Consequently, both profit shifting and its regulation via anti-avoidance rules come with benefits and costs. To be in a position to evaluate the implications of profit shifting, the need and design of regulation, the impact of tax havens, but also to understand the decision making in multinationals and their structure, it is first necessary to have a good understanding of

  • how the international tax environment functions,
  • how international tax regulation looks like, and
  • how multinationals minimize their global tax payments.

Following up on these issues, the course has three parts. Part 1 focuses on transfer pricing of intra-firm trade as a tax-avoidance channel (chapter 2). Part 2examines international debt shifting in a tax-efficient capital structure as a tool to save taxes (chapters 3 and 4). Finally, Part 3 discusses the institutional design and the effects of the most important anti-avoidance regulation (thin capitalization rules, controlled-foreign-company rules) in chapter 5.

The structure of the course roughly is as follows:
1. Introduction, Stylized Facts, and the International Tax System
2. Transfer Pricing and International Profit Shifting
3. Tax-efficient Capital Structures in Multinationals
4. Debt Shifting and Minority Ownership
5. Anti-avoidance Regulation: Thin Capitalization Rules, CFC rules

Leerdoelen

The aim of this course is to provide students with advanced (expert) knowledge on transfer pricing and debt shifting, and a thorough background in how international (corporate) taxation affects decision making in multinational companies. The course analyzes both strategies to optimize global corporate tax payments in multinational companies and their impact on investment decisions. It aims for embedding institutional details of tax systems and anti-avoidance regulation in theoretical models of behavior and for contrasting the theoretical insights with empirical evidence. The course has three parts. In a smaller part 1, transfer pricing of intra-firm trade as a tax-avoidance channel is discussed. A larger part 2 focuses on international debt shifting and adjustments in the firms’ capital structure as a tool to save taxes. Finally, part 3 presents, analyzes, and discusses the two most relevant anti-avoidance rules (thin capitalization and CFC rules).
After this course, students;

  • have an advanced understanding of the theory behind how international taxation affects firm behavior, how firms set up a tax-efficient financing structure, and how tax planning affects investment.
  • are informed about empirical evidence on both multinationals’ tax avoidance and its regulation.
  • know the main regulatory framework and institutional setting to limit international tax avoidance (arm’s length principle, thin capitalization rules, controlled-foreign-company rules).

Upon successful completion of the course, the students;

  • acquired an analytical tool set that allows for formally structuring and solving tax-avoidance problems, but also for evaluating the welfare impact of tax havens and the design of regulation.
  • can outline set-ups for independent empirical studies on profit shifting.
  • are able to independently analyze and evaluate the implications of future changes in regulation and the institutional setting.
  • can apply their knowledge on international tax avoidance and firms’ behavior in an abstract, but still meaningful way.

Furthermore, more generally, when having taken and successfully passed the course, the students should;

  • have advanced expertise on international income shifting by transfer prices and debt.
  • be able to evaluate pro and cons of profit shifting and its regulation.
  • be in a position to communicate with specialists in both academia and practice about complex issues in international tax avoidance and the BEPS debate.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar The set-up changes from two lectures à two hours (2+2) per week to two lectures with one three- and one two-hours lecture (3+2). This allows for more discussion, adding a new chapter, and more flexibility.

There will be an additional chapter on formula apportionment and the recent OECD Pillar I/II initiative. Extra The course is based in the profile Economic Policy, but open for International Economics and FEI students as well. Furthermore, it shall be a free elective for Finance students.
Lectures, exam, and answering the exam will take place in English.

The  final exam counts for 100%/85% (value will depend on assignment procedure) of the total score. The three-hour exam consists of short open questions and some standard (simple) derivations and calculations.
It is a closed-book exam, but non-programmable calculators are allowed. 
At the exam, students should be able to demonstrate a clear comprehension of the materials studied and discussed during the lectures.
Students will be required to make standard/simple mathematical derivations to describe firms’ behavior and identify comparative static effects. Importantly, the economic logic/reasoning/intuition for all results should be given in each question of the exam.
In addition, students should know about important institutional details (and important differences in regulation) and be able to interpret empirical findings.

Inhoud Contemporary culture is out of phase with technical progression, either considering it as a threat or as neutral matter to be exploited by humanity. According to the philosopher of technology Gilbert Simondon, both positions are inadequate. Instead, technology must be understood in its technicity, which is fully relational and involves a reconsideration of classical conceptual dualisms such as form and matter, design and production, work and life, all of which obscure the mode of existence of technical objects. In this intensive three-week workshop students will examine how the form and the function of technical objects have the capacity to transform both humans and environment. The aim is to extract knowledge from the readings and orient them into speculative research statements that will produce a series of material and technological experimentations as a final output. The students work in transdisciplinarily composed groups of max. 5 and are asked to produce a physical model that serves as the materialisation of their speculative research statement. In addition, they should prepare supplementary material to the model, such as drawings or short texts. The students are asked to present their models and other material in the end of the workshop in 20 min. presentations followed by (peer-)feedback. The products will be exhibited online. Leerdoelen

Upon completion of the three modules, the students will have:

o Acquired the academic skills for thinking, reading, presenting, and collaborating in an inclusive and transdisciplinary manner, in particular a sensibility for problems at the interface of architecture and philosophy;

o Acquired a conceptual toolbox for thinking in terms of relations and speculative-interactive design;

o Learned to apply contemporary ideas and debates in a dynamic urban setting in engaged, responsible, and non-reactive ways; Acquired or developed basic (technical) design skills while contributing to ecological literacy.

course_title: Techniques for Understanding Quantitative Secondary Data

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud In this practical, the student becomes familiar with, and learns to use different neuroscientific research techniques that can be used in forensic neuroscience, such as electroencephalography (EEG), (functional) Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI), and transcranial Current Stimulation (tCS). It is important that the student learns that, especially in this target group of forensic patients, neuroscientific research offers starting points for practice (including violence risk assessment and management), and is therefore an evidence-based approach.
In addition, the students will learn to use all this information on neuroscientific research techniques to write a report to the court as expert witness. Leerdoelen During this course, the student learns to:
  • Make an informed choice for different neuropsychological or neuroscientific methods to investigate suspects and perpetrators.
  • Explain in the role of expert witness on the basis of neuroscientific information why a particular punishment or measure is or is not appropriate for a particular suspect.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Course Overview Leerdoelen Learning Goals

In this course, you learn how digital technologies shape, improve or deteriorate fundamental human processes, such as attention, memory, and cognition. You learn that consumers make different decisions depending on the device-interface (e.g., touch versus voice interface) utilized and share more information about themselves when using a smartphone (as compared to another device). We will discuss the implications for individuals, society, and companies.
